div.head: To the Indifferent and Impartiall READER.
div.p:
BY this be pleased to take notice, that some people all over Yorkshire being turned Seekers, having turned out prayer, preaching, and the Ordinances of God, and counting them too low things to follow, the Old Seeker,2 Pet. 5.8. who goes about continually seeking whom he may devour, hath falne upon them, and drawn them into absurd, and unreasonable both principles and practices, by running up and down the Country to act in quakings and transes, and drawing many after them to leave Ordinances, Callings, Relations, and despite both Nature and Grace at once. One, piously intending by thirty Quaeries propounded, to warne them that stand, and waken them are falne, to see into what a pitifull pit of errours they are falne, hath beene furiously set upon by an Advocate for them, whom they judge more Schollar, and fitter to answer then themselves. He is a Seeker, but no profest Quaker, but willing to defend any thing save Truth. He hath answered the Quaeries in three sheets with Antiquaeries, which his Admirers commend and extoll as a rare piece, and so it is, as a key-gun is a rare piece of Ordnance to a little boy, if it spit with a little fire and Gunpowder. This indeed hath much of Schoolship and Divinity in it, if Railing be Reasoning and Vanity Divinity. It seemes he waited for an opportunity, and was glad he got it, to blaspheme the Ministery, and preaching of the Gospell in print. He hath done it so fully, that the
Quaerer was loath to answer him, and thought this a sufficient and large enough Answer.Eccles. 10.13. The beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishnesse, and the end of his talke mischievous madnesse; being of this minde, that Reason is worth answering, Absurdities answer themselves. Yet lest the ignorant should crow like Cocks of the game, and Masters of the Pit, they should be hardned in errours, and others by seeming flourishes seduced, a friend to the Quaerer hath taken up his defence, in officiousnesse to serve the truth,Eccles. 7.9. who therefore earnestly desires rather to have truth and meeknesse rest in his bosome, then that which rests in the bosome of fooles. If the Antiquaerer shall come againe, this Replier promises, he shall have leave upon his owne paper stage to wrastle, wrangle, reproach and Scuffle by himselfe. Onely Reader know this, you shall find nothing here relating to these Quakers tenents and doings, but what is true, and will be made good, and from their opinions all from their owne words and papers. All this is done, and the Lord make it effectuall for this purpose; to reclaime wandring soules, to settle staggering soules, to warne all provident and cautious soules, to looke to themselves and get to be grounded in the truth. For Satan, seeing how weakly and poorely many soules were founded, and built up in the knowledge of Christ and his Gospell, sent out his messengers with this hope.Nehem. 4.3. That which these ignorant soules so ungroundedly build, if a Foxe goe up, he shall even break downe their stone wall. He hath sent a Foxe, and he hath done it, many are falne being weake, and unwary, and but built upon the sand. Consider the Antiquaerer and the Replies,Judg. 19.20. let Truth beare the greatest weight, Umpire and Judge by the Sentence of Truth and word of God, and this is all that is desired. Consider of it, take advice, and speake your mindes.

div.head: The Quaeries being but short, you shall have here the Quaeries, the Antiquaeries in each part needfull, and the Reply to them.
QƲAERIE I.
div.p: WHether they have any other warrant to put themselves into those quaking, and trembling postures, then those generall parts of the word, which commend the working out Salvation with fear and trembling? Trembling at the word, serving the Lord with fear, and rejoycing before him with trembling, &c.

div.head: The Antiquaerie.
div.p: Whether this man, who propounds these Quaeries, speake soberly, or rashly, if not maliciously, of that he understands not, when as he saith in his first Quaerie, they put themselves into quaking and trembling postures? whereas it is a thing, which they cannot avoid and flie from.

div.head: The Reply to the Antiquaerie.
div.p:
For the Quaeries, whether it were soberly, rashly, maliciously or ignorantly propounded is the Antiqueries demand? I will answer for you, and tell you your judgement such as it is, you meane one Negative and three Affirmatives. Namely, it was not soberly, there is the Negative; but you give him three Affirmative lyes for it, rashly, maliciously, and ignorantly. Here is too much for the Quaerer, I pray you being of the Family of love take some of them to your selfe; and give leave to say, that the Antiquaerer saith many things ignorantly and maliciously also. Here comes in all the rashnesse, ignorance, and malice, that the Quaerer saith, they put themselves into quaking and trembling postures, whereas the Antiquaerer saith, it is a thing they cannot
avoid or flie from. Why may it not be thought they put themselves into these postures and prankes? Have not some of their brethren the false Prophets said, when they Prophesied, they were put upon it by the Lord, by visions and dreames from him, when the Lord neither appeared to them, nor spoke one word to them? Thus saith the Lord of hostes, (concerning the false Prophets) Hearken not unto the words of the prophets that prophesie unto you: Jerem. 23.16. they make you vaine, they speake a vision of their owne heart, and not out of the mouth of the Lord. Jer. 23.25, 26. I have heard what the prophets said, that prophesie lies in my name, saying, I have dreamed, I have dreamed, —yea they are Prophets of the deceit of their owne heart. Have the pride, vanity and delusions of their spirits got such a power over them, as it is turned into a holy rage and violence, and they cannot avoid it, or flie from it? I have more charity, Mr. Advocate, for them then you, you say they cannot avoid it, I say they will not avoid it; For they thinke it is the divine inspiration, (though it be meere delusion) and they will not though they could avoid it, for they judge that were resisting of high motions. But whom shall we believe in this businesse, you or them? you say, they cannot avoid it, you never quaked nor played a Transers part, you cannot tell, yea but they tell you so. Know you not that many Clients make bad causes good to their Advocates, till they come to be pleaded and witnessed publiquely, and then the Advocate is ashamed of his Clients and his cause? Now that you may know something from the Ancient Traders in this way, for it is an old Love lock cut off from Satans head, and now growing into fashion againe, I shall relate you what of old was practised in this kinde, and judge whether it were not likely to be more voluntarie, then violent and enforced, it is from the relation of holy Zuinglius, when the Church of Zurick was extreamly pestred with these Catabaptistick, Extatick, Enthusiasts; There was (saith he) among the Catabaptists at Sangall, a young wench of twelve yeares old, or somewhat upward, the daughter of a right minded Father.Zuing. Ep. l. 2. in Elench. ad ver. Catabapt. He being about going abroad to carry forth Corne, for his calling was that way, his daughter advised him to stay that day at home, and he should see wonderfull things. Some while after the wilie girle falls into her Transe, lies as it were in an extasie, and when she comes out, she babbled
any fanaticall vaine thing as she saw good. His Observation, I meane Zuinglius, upon it is this; you see, saith he, she knew before hand when she should fall; And the reason why she fell not before, when she saw her Father about to goe forth, was, she was not yet fully instructed and taught, she waited for some thing that she further needed to fit her for her businesse.

And further he saith, as one that knew it, that they used to cast themselves suddenly downe, as if they were Epileptick, taken with the falling sicknesse, holding their breath in as long as ever they can, and faining themselves to be in an extasie, give a fearefull appearance to them that looke on them, and then comming out, as if they were awakened, they tell you strange things they have both seen and learnt. Judge now whether ours be not as like to these, as Egge to Egge. Holy men, that saw them, judged there was no force, but faining; no violence▪ but what was from their owne voluntary contrivance and collusion. Besides, ours tell us, when they come out of their fits, no strange things, but what they commonly said before, Repent, Repent, woe, woe, or the day of wrath is comming against such and such, &c. Withall, it is, or may be knowne to you and others, that they are seldome or never entransed in their Extaticall Quakings, but before others and in company, because the speech at the end of their quaking, is the maine end of their quaking, by it to perswade a Divinity is upon them to their credulous Auditors and spectators. Lastly, I could answer you, you doe like a corrupt Advocate flatter your Client in a bad cause, and put fairest glosses and colours upon it, when the cause is not good; and if it were as you say, that they were forced, it is so much the worse, and is more like the raptures that the Priests of Apollo, and other deliverers of Oracles of the Devils were taken with, and were violently forced to doe and speake as they did, and could not avoid it.Peucer. in Commentar. de Divinat. Genereb. praecip. Tit. de Orac. Yea Apollo's she Priests first drunke of a water in a secret place of the Temple, and after the draught they were enforced into a fit of prophesying. Though I say nothing in comparison to it of your womans bottle, not troubling my selfe to seeke out that, which has beene witnessed by some. The water, the Pythian she Priests drunke off, was such a water, as would quench
burning brands or tapers, being held neere to it, and being held a good way off would kindle and light them againe being quencht. And it is well knowne that in a strange enforced rapture or fury all the devilish Priests delivered the Oracles. So that it is little for their credit, that you say they are enforced, your defence is offensive to their way for the credit and Divineness of it. When they gave out answers they did it with an horrible sound & noyse, they were furiously acted and moved, there was trembling and palpitation of all their joynts. Thus did not the prophets of God undergoe a like violence in their visions, and divine occurrencies.
Tell us of lesse violence and force in yours, and we shall thinke more softly of it: but if you say it is enforced, you will force us into a suspicion of it.

div.head: QƲERE II.
div.p: Whether when holy trembling and feare is commended in Scriptures, there be meant any other ordinarily, then the Spirituall and holy dread in the soule, to stand in awe of God, repent before him, and to walk humbly with the Lord?

div.head: Antiquer. Replie.
div.p: Why dost thou put in the word Ordinarily? It seemes thou thy self darest not exclude an extraordinary trembling, to be comprehended in those scriptures; and if it be comprehended at all in any of them, it is sufficient, &c.

div.head: Replie to Antiquer.
div.p:
There was Reason to put in the word Ordinarily, because Extraordinary things fall not under Rule; nor common practise But quaking with noyse and strange motions is ordinary with the people that worship your strong imaginations▪ I had almost said, that have sent upon them strong delusions to believe lies. Yet you are resolved on it, if the Scripture speake of any extraordinary tremblings; it is enough to justifie yours. Now sute Master Advocate you have not Littleton for this, and Scripture will not serve you to justifie it. If it be comprehended in any, you say it serves.Sam. 19.15. I perceive any thing will serve you. Will this serve you? There was a trembling in the hoste of the Philistims they trembled and quaked and it was a very great trembling, or as trembling of God. I judge this will not serve you, though comprehended in
Scriptures, for this was an extraordinary quaking sent upon the Philistims and not upon Israel, you would not have your Clients taken for Philistims. I shall come to your minde, in those Scriptures, that is, in those mentioned in the Quaere, and where trembling is not onely comprehended but commended. Well, in those Scriptures of standing in awe, Psal. 4. Repenting before the Lord and walk humbly with God, Mic. 6. I doe not conceive there is commended or comprehended any extraordinary trembling, but what is or should be ordinary in every holy soule, that is of a meeke, melting, humble, holy spirit, that feares the Lord and his goodnesse. You will hardly have Rhetorique enough to perswade any solid Christians, that if they will doe as all former Saints did, stand in awe of God, and walke humbly with the Lord, they must needes turne into entransings and quakings. Doe not you know, that the feare and holy awe of the soule was as well, and better evidenced by studying to observe Gods commands, and to depart from evill, then by any wrestings or wringings of the body into Antique appearances? Then you tell us that some of the servants of God have beene shaken, as if all their bones were out of joynt, and made to roare, and that is sufficient to prove it, because David, though a strong one,Zach. 12.8. was a type of the weake ones, and you say, he that is weake shall be as David. Davids bones being as it were out of joynt, his being shaken and his roaring, if you doe not, others understand it thus, that by these phrases expressing paine and trouble in the body, is not meant any other then the fearefull and sad state of his troubled soule, by apprehending the grievousnesse of Gods anger against him for sinne, the heavy evill of Gods clouding his face, and hiding the joy of his salvation from him. His roaring was his earnestnesse of praying, calling, sighing after God. He perhaps might not speake one word, when he sometimes roared unto God, for the earnest and holy applyings of the troubled soule to God, by humble, penitent, believing sighs and groanes are roarings,Exod. 14.15. and better then loudest cries in Gods eares. The Lord said to Moses, why cryest thou to me? We heare not of his crying, but we are sure his soule cryed and roared with the high language of faith, and earnest, zealous, secret and spirituall pleadings with God,1 Sam. 1. better then all words. So Hanah spoke in her heart to the Lord, and
yet the Lord heard it. David may mention his roaring to God, when he spoke it may be in a word: and his bones being all as it were out of joint and shaken, when the body shewed no outward motion, but it was the commotion and trouble of his distempered soule and spirit. For that Scripture of Zacharie, The weake shall be as David▪ applied unto Davids quaking and roaring, it is a childs arrow shot without aiming at any marke, or a wrong marke. Indeed when God hides his face from weake soules, they shall be sh • ken and troubled in their spirits, as David was, in some measure. But what is this to falling on the ground and quaking? you may abuse other things with lesse guilt then abuse the Scripture. Let me set you right here without any abusing you, or the prophet Zacharie. The meaning of this is, the weak shall be as David, that is, when God shall visit his Church with grace and mercy, and they shall repent and turne to him, he will blesse them all, and make the weake soules that had falne, upon their repentance, rise up with as much courage, joy, and spirituall strength to walke in the service of the Lord, as David did. He will not onely shew mercy to the strong ones, but he will protect the weak ones also, and make them strong in faith and comforts of faith, as David was.

Esay 2.4.12, 13 Esay 23.9. Esay 2.18.19, 20, 21.The rest that you have in the Antiquerie are but flourishes of swords you speake beaten into plough shares; of every one that is high and lifted up to be brought low, the Honourable brought to contempt: Idols of silver and gold cast to Moles and Bats for feare of the Lord and glory of his Majestie, when he arises to shake terribly the earth. Do you thinke all the overturnings of Kingdomes, People, places threatned in Scripture are proofes and arguments with an Ergo, we must fall into a Transe after this manner? It is a good Argument, since God will so exalt his power and justice against sinners, therefore we ought to search and try our waies and turne unto him; since God comes to humble and bring downe all that is proud and high. If I were a Preacher, with your leave I would make this use of it: Let us humble our selves by repentance and seeke to the Lord for mercy, that when he comes to humble all the lofty of the earth, he may finde us kindely and rightly humble to his hand. This humbling and turning penitents, may be, I judge, without turning Quakers.
—At last you tell us, these things are foretold, & must come to pass, & how shall they be Ordinary when they seldome, or never were before? — What doe you meane? Were the Honourable of the earth never humbled before? Did the Lord never shake the earth before? There have beene great alterations in Church and State before your time and mine. God has heretofore poured out the fury of warre, plagues, famines, depopulations, and strong judgements in the dayes of our Ancestors, yea from the beginning of the world. Are you in a Transe too, that you say these were seldome or never before, and then how should they be Ordinary? I pray consider your selfe, and minde what you write; if this be believed by you, your judgement is but very ordinary, and theirs so too that depend upon it.

div.head: QƲERE III.
div.p: Whether it were Ordinary in the Old and New Testament for the holy Servants of God to quake, be entransed, make strange noyses, shew strange swellings and stirrings of the body, as if they were possest with some spirit?

div.head: Antiquerie.
div.p: Whether dost not thou render this worke under as odious termes as thou canst, to enrage every one against them, upon whom it falls? — Was not roaring and mourning like Doves strange noyses? Was not Peter entransed, and Paul rapt up, and John caught up in the spirit higher and higher, to heare and see the mysteries of God opened? And yet thou darest revile the dealings of the Lord with his Servants.

div.head: Replie to the Antiquerie.
div.p:
There are no odious termes put upon this worke, but such as are the lively and naturall representations of the actions themselves: for are they not seene accompanied with quakings, swellings and stirrings of the body? you are pleased to make a second stumble at the word (Ordinary) which was spoken to above, and it may well be used in the Querie, because Peters entransing, and Pauls falling to the earth astonished, and such like, were extraordinary, and so cannot fall under such ordinary and common expectation, as to let every one of your way looke for it. For roaring and mourning like Doves, you aske if these were not strange noyses? I answer as before, it was more in the inward
passionate desires, and sighing of the soule complaining secretly to God, then any outward noyse from the body. Actings of the soul commonly are set out by borrowing expressions from the body and other creatures, as mourning like Doves, chattering like Cranes.

At last you write such things as I wonder you quake not so to abuse Scripture, and apply the Lords dealings with some of his Saints, to the trembling and odde fits of your deceived Proselytes. What a base comparison is this, to compare Peters entransing, Pauls being rapt up into Heaven, Johns being taken up in the Spirit, to those unspirit like actions & passions of men & women lying upon the ground, or throwing themselves upon a bed? O the blindnesse of a man set and bent to maintaine fancies! Peters was a supernaturall and extraordinary case, when he was called by a Vision from God to turne in to the Gentiles. In the Vision there was the opening of the Heavens shewed to him, a sheet let down as it were from Heaven, Act. 20.11, 12, &c. a voice from Heaven calling upon him, and the spirit telling him, that three men were seeking him; and besides all this, Peter was seeking God by prayer. We know no voyce yours have from Heaven, no vision but of their owne braine, no extraordinary businesse that they are called to more then others, and for prayer and the Ordinances they may lye for ever in a Transe, they use them not, unlesse it be as you use the Scriptures here, to wrong and abuse them. Then Pauls being wrapt up into Heaven, 2 Cor. 12. must be a patterne for their being rapt downe to the earth. Feare you not thus to wrest and wring the holy Scriptures of God, to give an Heavenly passe to your wretched follies, the vile froth of seduced hearts? The Lord open your eyes to see how unworthily you deale with his sacred writings. I appeale to any that hath any savoury knowledge or taste of the things of the word of God, whether Pauls being wrapt up into Heaven, into Paradise, have any similitude or likenesse to these strange lyings of divers men and women, heads and points upon the earth, unlesse they thinke there is nothing liker Heaven then this. Johns being caught up in the Spirit must be brought in too, for these they tell us, see mysteries, yea and so see we too, the mystery of Familisme in you, or the mystery of strong delusions, the mysteries of a spirit of giddinesse. But Sir, you defend them
not well enough, they have in their writings set us downe a great many Scriptures, wherein they finde quaking and trembling better then these you bring by the head and shoulders. David said,Psal. 119.120. My flesh trembleth for fear of thee, and I am afraid of thy Judgements. Paul trembled, Acts 9. we heare of Habakkucks trembling,Acts 9. Habak. 3. Heb. 12. Moses his feare and quaking, and many others. And their inference is this, thererefore Moses, Habakkuck, David, Paul, were all patrons of the quakers. Nay, they tell us,Phil. 2.12. we are bid to worke out our Salvation with feare and trembling, and therefore all are to quake: and if this be not good Logick, aske Thomas Aldam, surely it makes but odde Divinity, this to squeeze and presse the Scriptures. I could shew you how in this you deale with the word of God, as the Alchymists doe,Quantum Astrenomi metiuntur, tantum Astrologi mentiuntur Marcil. Ficinus. who bring a great many Scriptures to prove the Phylosophers stone, and the seeking for it. Thus Astrologers who oft-times make lyes heavenly wide, bring Scriptures to patronize reading all things in the Stars and Planets. God gave these holy writings to shine and leade us into light, not to carry us into darknesse, and not to bend and bow them to our owne darke ends.

div.head: QƲAERE IV.
div.p: Whether if they heap up all Scriptures, that mention trembling and quaking, they may not put in this also, the Devils beleeve and tremble?

div.head: The Antiquaerie.
div.p: Whether this discover not an heart filled with maliciousnesse and indignation? For out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaketh. And secondly, whether this be not a Contradiction to the 14. Quaere, where thou sayest they make nothing of the outward Command of the word?

div.head: The Reply to the Antiquaerie.
div.p:
It may be the Quaerers heart was full of Indignation, and so is mine too against such strange injurers of the spirit of God, and word of God, that none da • e bring Scriptures, as the Devill quoted one place, to perswade Christ to breake his neck by Scripture. The Quaerer may keepe his holy Indignation, and leave the unholy maliciousnesse to you.2 Cor. 7.11. Esay 66.14. For there may be indignation without malice, as to Saints, & to God himself acts of indignation are sometimes assigned. For that of the Devills beleeving and trembling it should not seeme strange to you, whose principles
are so large and comprehensive, as you have beene ready not only to have been an Advocate for the Quakers, but an Advocate for the Devills also to plead for them & their salvation. For your people bragging all over, you are the Author of these Antiquaeries, may heare this also or reade it, that you are ready to prove not onely saveablenesse, but that the lost Ang • lls shall be saved. What strange thing should you make it then, that the Quaerer tells you the D • vills beleeving and trembling might be brought in, with trembling also of Men and Women that shall be saved? You know this well can be made good by divers witnesses, that you alledged Scripture to prove it, and as strange a Scripture for that purpose as might be. This is your Gospell or glad tydings for the falne Angells in Zacharie. As for thee also by the blood of the Covenant, Zach 9.11. I have sent forth thy Prisoners out of the pit wherein is no water. I never heard that this was the Devills Gospel before, but I perceive Seekers find unsound things to pitch upon, rather then truth. Any that have but ordinary inspection into the Bible will tell you, that these prisoners of hope are the Jews, that the pit without water is the Babylonian Captivity, and that the blood of the Covenant is the blood of Christ shadowed out by the blood of the Sacrifices, Exod. 24.8. Heb. 13.20. And that Christs blood was shed for them from whom he tooke fl • sh and blood. Now he took not on him the nature of Angells, but he took on him the seed of Abraham, Heb 2.14. and this was, since the children are partakers of flesh and blood to save them and to destroy through death him that had the power of death, that is, the Devil. Destroying is a contrary way to saving. I would not have you write commentaries on Scripture, for you would in Zacharie make the Devills Saints, such as should be saved, or else you would make the Jews Devills, and Babylons captivity Hell. I could have told you of many Scriptures fitter to your purpose,Mark. 16.15. with far better colour. As that, preach the Gospell to every creature, if to every creature, then to falne Angels, for they are creatures. Yet this would prove very weake to any solid soule, it may serve with jeat judgements, that draw chaffe and light strawes to them. Those that heare of the right hands Venite into everlasting life, have reason to judge that the left hands Ite into everlasting fire is equally everlasting with it,Mat. 25.46. and without end. Make you not that long lasting onely which God makes
everlasting. This is onely by the way, to shew your squeamish stomack at this of bringing in the Devils beleeving and trembling, when your selfe well knowes this will be justified to your face as your Orthodoxe opinion, you thinke after some time the Devills sh • ll be saved. You may set downe the time, but the Scriptures and Oracles of God set downe none.

The last thing in your Antiquaerie is this, that this seemes to be the Quaerers contradiction of himselfe, who in his 14. Quaere saith, the Quakers make nothing of the outward Command of the word. You will doe well, if you will consider these words a litle better, Advocates had need to be advised lest they overshoote themselves. The Devills beleeve and tremble, doe these words carry the nature of a command? is there any command or precept in them? Doth God command, or James command any thing by this? It is a plaine proposition, or assertion of the sad state of the Devils, that they beleeve but it is a wofull beleefe full of application of eternal discomfort & undergoing of Gods wrath. Many things are in the written word that are not commands of God, some of them are words of the Devill, as All these things will I give thee, if thou wilt fall downe and worship me. This is to waken you, having an adversary, to looke and examine what you write; you take advantage where it is not given you, others will take advantage, yea though in a good cause, much more will advantage be taken when one deals in a bad cause.

div.head: QƲAERE V.
div.p: Whether the Spirit, that this people are led by, be a good Spirit, because they are led into disorders? but Gods Spirit is a Spirit of Order.

div.head: The Antiquaerie.
div.p: Whether to assemble together in a peaceable, harmelesse way, be disorder? Whether did Christ or any of the Apostles judge the flocking together of the people after truth to be disorder, though the world counted it a turning of all upside downe?

div.head: The Reply to the Antiquaery.
div.p:
No great adoe shall we make here for answer. For some of yours I shall passe over briefly, as having little matter in them worth answering; your peoples assembling is said to be in a peaceable, harmlesse way, and therefore cannot be disorder, you say so, it is not so. Is this a peaceable and harmlesse way for a
man to leave his wife and children, to run about, and let them shift for themselves? Or is this a peaceable and harmlesse way for Wives to leave their Husbands against their wills? you know there were women at the Assizes accused for this, the leaving their Husbands, and they professed they would doe it. I perceive any thing is peaceable and harmlesse that sets up this running trade any way. I thought this had been disorder, that any should voluntarily leap out of that calling, and breake off that Relation God had set & fixt them in, and this should be done of their own heads, and with much headinesse. I thought this had been disorder to stand up in orderly Assemblyes of Gods people, to interrupt Ministers and teachers of the word of God. For the rest I am ashamed of the comparison, that you should say Christ and his Apostles never blamed the people for flocking after the truth, they had no reason to doe it. But what if they had done as these, flocked after dotages and errours, would they not have blamed them? yes, sure I am. Do these that despise and raile at preaching of the Gospell, Baptisme, Supper, &c. doe these flock after truth? I will have none of that truth that despises the word of truth.

div.head: QƲAERE VI.
div.p: Whether they have not the word of God as a shadow, when they make it stand by at their pleasure? As when the man will leave the Wife, or Wife the Husband to follow their Circumcellion walkes and roving about.

div.head: The Antiquaerie.
div.p: Whether doth Christ plainly put his servants sometimes upon forsaking all for his sake, Houses, Brethren, Sisters, Father, Mother, Wife, Children, Lands? Mat. 19.29.— And for the word Circumcellion, why dost thou use a dark word so improperly? which of them are Alehouse or Taverne-hanters?

div.head: The Reply to the Antiquaery.
div.p:
Two things I have to say to the first part of forsaking all for Christs sake. First, that it is possible there may be a forsaking of all for Christ, without any locall secession, or breaking from the society of Husband, Wife, Children, &c. The excellentest part of forsaking is in the heart, and acted about the affections & will, wholly given up to Christ, though outward callings and actions be still used. Secondly, that this new kinde of forsaking all hath no
more likenesse of doing it for Christ, then London is like Constantinople, or your Towne is like Mexico. For this you call a forsaking all for Christ, is but a changing of the objects of your pleasures, and changing for a fancies sake, not for faiths sake. If you be a Seeker, you may seeke long enough, ere you can make their practises agree with Christs Rule. (I passe by your generall charge against the Querer, you being 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , an evill speaker and slanderer in it, and there being no appearance of any thing but unlearned passions) then you come to the word Circumcellion, and aske the Querer why he uses such a darke word so improperly? which of these he blames are Ale-house or Taverne-haunters?

For this word Circumcellion, which you call a darke word, I shall inlighten the darknesse of it to you; I pitty your Schollersh p is so dimme and duskie, that you know not what it meanes; I dare not tell you, that had you stept but a litle into Austin, one of the learnedst and most considerable African Christians, you might easily have plowed with his heifer, and knowne it. Circumcellions were a branch of the sect of the Donatists, but that may be a darke word to you also. The Donatists were a sect in Africa like your Perfectists and Quakers, that held the Church was no where but among them, they were pure without spot and wrinkle, the best must be Baptized againe, that joyne with them; all were sinners and unclean but they. They slandered, and to their power persecuted all that went not their way; you know who doth so. They held none were to be urged by any authority and power to live well, but to use their owne liberty or licence rather: Magistrates with them were not to meddle with Hereticks by any acts of coercion, & divers other deliriums they maintained. Among them were some called Circumcelliones, the busiest, boldest, and the seditiousest sort of them, running about and watching opportunities, where they were strong enough, to speak all evill, and deale blowes and wounds to them were not of their cut. And because as in a winters night, you crie hang out a light, by the sound of the word Circumcellions, presently dreaming of a dark Wine-cellar, or some blinde Ale-house; I shall quit you of that suspicion. They were so called from certaine Cells and little Cottages they had in the fields, in which they would give appearance
of their living an austere, Genus hominum agreate & famofissimae audaeiae. Aug. de Haeres. ad Quod vult deum. c. 99. rigid, and solitarie life, though thence they runne out, and meeting those that bowed not to their imaginations; they beat, robb'd, wounded and killed some. Sir, Circumcellions I called yours, for running far from home, roving about, and interrupting Ministers, and Assemblies of people, orderly abiding in the worship of God, threatning, cursing, and giving bitter language. You may read enough of these other in Austins Epistles; and in Optatus you shall finde that these roaring Sectaries running about,Circumeellicnum insani duces nominabant se Sanctorum Duces. Optat. contra. Parmenian. lib. 3. called their Ringleaders, the Leaders and Captaines of the Saints. I know your Clients thinke the Leaders of them taller then any we count Saints, by the head and shoulders. I shall leave this Antiquerie with this, though they be not Taverne and Ale-house haunters, yet they may be as bad, being drunke and quite typsie in Satans cellar with pride, conceit of perfection, censuring and damning all others, busie-bodies, turbulent, so as that may be applyed to them.Esay 29.9. They are drunke, but not with wine: Since Circumcellion so stumble you, I am sure our Antiquerer is no Antiquarie, unlesse it be in defending old errours, and yet he thinkes it new light.

div.head: QƲERE VII.
div.p: Whether the Apostle is to be justified in saying, Let every one abide in his owne calling, in so doing he abideth with God; or those parties are to be justified more, that leave their callings and families, and take up the trade of the spirit, that runs about and compasses the earth?

div.head: Antiquer.
div.p: Whether the thousands of Believers spoken of in the Acts of the Apostles, did not abide in that calling wherewith they were called of God, although they sold up what they had, and lived together? And if these should doe so, whether doth this man know they doe not abide in that calling to which they are called of God?

div.head: Replie to Antiquerie.
div.p:
First I will give you answer to this part of your plea. Those in the Acts did abide in their callings, did not run away from wives and children, did not leave their debts unpaid to betake themselves to that holy way of living together for a while, did not cease living in some honest exercise; prove you the contrary if you can. For that they sold up what they had and lived together,
when we know what you will make of this, I shall thinke you worthy an answer. If you drive at community, that place of the Acts will not serve you. Yours selling up their goods to that purpose we see not, but some we see very willing to live upon others. At length you come to an If, if these should do so, whether doth this man know, &c. Good Sir, stop there, for this Man might tell you he knowes two things. 1. He knowes these do not so, nay they are far from doing like to the primitive Christians as yet. 2. He knowes againe that they now walke irregularly, and out of their callings.

First, they do not so as the former did, for besides communicating of their goods and supplies to their brethrens necessities, they continued daily with one accord in the Temple, Acts 2.46, 47. these neither can endure the place of Gods publique worship, nor those that use it. They praised God, and had favour with all the people, and did eate their bread with gladnesse and singlenesse of heart. We heare nothing of your mens strange prankes among them. I know your minde, you would have all common. But you are deceived in that point, for those rare Saints at first entertaining of the Gospell, though they had large charity to relieve the wanting, yet might keepe propriety and distribute as they would, they might sell a part, and keepe a part for themselves, unlesse they publikely promised and devoted all they had that way, as may be seene in the case of Ananias. Ours need not to doe so, the Apostles gave no such Doctrine to the Churches of the Gentiles, but to love, relieve, and succour one another. If without this Communion you would have no Apostolicall Church, then the Apostles rightly planted no Churches, for they planted none as you meane in this Community of goods, when the Church and Gospel spread after the first beginnings, but Christians possessed houses, and goods, and servants of their owne, or else what need Paul tell of collections? we heare of Tabitha, she had an house, riches,1 Cor. 16. Acts 9. and gave great Almes. We heare of the Saints at Antioch, making large contributions, to the beleevers at want in Jerusalem and Judea.

Secondly, he knowes yours walke irregularly. For whereas one should live in the East, he neglects Wife, Children, calling, and roaving in the West. Others of the West are roaving in the East:
and whereas they are fitted by God for some mechannick callings, they must needs turne preachers, for they are learned in two great bookes, Ignorance and Impudence. God never calls these thus.—The rest that you talke and write, is like a man in a dreame, of some denying themselves riches, pleasures, honours, and of others that wrest the Scriptures; shew us yours denying riches, pleasures, honours wholly and holily, they doe neither this way. Shew us who wrest Scriptures more then your selfe and yours. Shew us one Scripture wrested, and you shall have either satisfaction, or confession, or both.

div.head: QƲAERIE VIII.
div.p: Whether they walk according to the rule, Whatsoever ye would that men should doe to you, &c. when they leave houses, sell up their goods, and make their Creditors lose many and great debts, &c.

div.head: The Antiquery.
div.p: Whether dost not thou rather break that rule when thou wouldest enrage and stir up people and Magistrates, and all to swallow them up and make an end of them?

div.head: The Reply to the Antiquaery.
div.p:
I shall quickly make an end of this, people and M • gistrates by the rule of Verity and Charity, may be stirred up to take heede of these, and hinder their spreading; and though not to make an end of the persons, or to swallow them up, yet to helpe to the making an end, and swallowing up of their errours, then to let them alone, and let them be swallowed downe.—There is something else but of quaering and questioning, whether the Quaerer doe not break the rule himselfe? I tell you in this he doth not, but I passe it, for it is a begger very worthie of a passe. Then you come, But whether dost thou know any of them to make no conscience of defrauding their Creditors? I know but some of them saith our Antiquaerer, and I know they make Conscience to discharge their debts to their powers. You bring to my minde how Advocates agree at a breakfast,Correctio tollit id quod dictum est, & pro eo, quod magis idoneum videtur reponit. Voss. in Institut. Orator. l. 5. though they fall out in the Court. You say, dost thou know any? yes if you will, the Quaerer will helpe me, and you too with their Names, that leave their Houses and Callings for a long time, and the Creditors thinke of nothing but a whistle. But neither he, nor I intend against persons, but errors. Yet what needs this
twixt you and me, when in next words you say, I know but some of them? I never found a piece of Schollarship with you but this, and it is a corrupt piece of humane Rhetorique, though you minde it not, a figure with a darke word like Circumcellion, called Epanorthosis, when a man having said something, presently corrects himselfe in what he said, and makes some kinde of minced confession of that he had renounced.Correctio est quae posteriori comitate prius positum emendat. Susenbrot. Schem. Rhet. I see all humane learning is not cast off by you, you love a little Rhetorique, Susenbrotus is no Ephesian conjuring booke with you, and to be burnt.

I pray you take notice how this cloth shrinkes in the pressing. Dost thou know any? and then it followes, I know but some. Put some and any together, Doe those some well? No, they doe not yet. But you say, I know they doe make Conscience to discharge their debts to their power. It were well their Creditors knew it. What power can they have so to doe it, when they neglect their Callings? If ever idlenesse and neglect of Callings, cloathed a man with beggery and ragges, these sad and ragged dayes much more will doe it. If ever dayes called for honest providence and diligence, these doe. It were well you could perswade the Creditors to be of your faith, for some of these say all is theirs, and they shall judge the world, and then let the Creditors looke to themselves, they will judge them worthy to goe without their debts.

Remember Sir, I leave you well in the end of this Antiquaery, in plaine confession. I see there is some ingenuity in you, you know something as well as the Quaerer, but you must needs speak something for your Client.

div.head: QƲAERIE IX.
div.p: Whether this Wisdome of theirs be from Heaven, which is followed with this charity to call all damned and children of the Devill, whether they know them or know them not, that walke not their way?

div.head: The Antiquaerie.
div.p: I cannot finde this to be true. But suppose some speake rashly, must this be clapt upon the backs of others that approve not of it? &c.

div.head: The Reply to the Antiquaerie.
div.p:
If you finde it not to be true, yet the severall Congregations and Market places, where they have stood up and railed upon
Ministers and people, it may be they never saw before will make it true. And for clapping it upon the backs of others, I must tell you, there is some reason to apply it to all, because first the most use this way. Secondly, because the chiefe and leaders of the others doe it, as might be shewne you by a score of their letters, all writ with sharpest vineger to persons, many of them they know not. Then you bring in a salvo for this, that when mens words and deeds discover them what they are, (that is, no Quakers,) there is no want of charity, or heavenly wisdome, if the Spirit of God shall so in one of them pronounce it against another. I never knew before that the Spirit of God did pronounce rash, railing, and hellish language. You know not what spirit you are of. After this you bring three instances of Christ, Peter, and Paul, to justifie the hellish language of your fellow-Creatures. Christ told the Jews, you are of your Father the Devill. Peter told Simon Magus, thou art in the gall of bitternesse. Paul said to Elias the Sorcerer, thou child of the Devill, &c. How great is your uncharitablenesse and hellish maliciousnesse? Is every Christian walkes not your way as bad as a Jew, and of his Father the Devill, though he be never so holy and honest? Is every Christian man and Minister a Conjurer, as ill a Sinner as Eli was, because he cannot say your darknesse is light? The Lord turne your spirits into a more soft and sanctified temper. Paul, and Peter, and Christ could see further then yours can, and could spie they were incurable wretches, for we here tell of a spirit of discerning. You tell us afterwards of letting tares alone, but here you allow of plucking up wheat, & not letting it alone, but blasting and blaspheming it. The Lord give you more right faith, and right charity too, you need both.

div.head: QƲAERE X.
div.p: Whether they be not possessed with an higher and holier spirit then Paul, who gave Agrippa, Festus and Felix their Titles, and behaved himselfe submissively and modestly? these Thou and revile, and scornfully contemne all Superiors and Magistrates.

div.head: The Antiquaerie.
div.p: Whether are all Magistrates to be honoured alike? &c.

div.head: The Reply to the Antiquaerie.
div.p:
The office is to be honoured in all, it is the Ordinance of
God. The abuse of the office may be spoken of seasonably and soberly, but without railing, and cursed contempt.Psal. 15.4. You aske whether one that dwells in God, or as one would say with God, is not charactered to be a despiser of a vile person. For that, there is no taking away of civill honour from any man, since the Apostles commanded service and obedience to Heathen Rulers for the Lords sake, because power and authority was a Divine Ordinance. The Prophet doth not so much looke at persons as manners, that we should despise, not sooth, humour and flatter them in unjust and sinfull wayes, but shew our dislike and displeasure. That of the Psalme is not so much of Magistrates, as of all other, or any other vicious and lewd men, of bad and naughty conversations; we should contemne them, that is, we should avoid their society, we should not make them men of our countenance, Counsells, Company, our familiar friends; we should withdraw from them, and shew our dislike of their wayes, Ephes. 5. Paul when there was no danger of adoration, gave honourable termes to Agrippa, and called an Heathen Magistrate, Noble Festus. Rex curru paulo ante vectus, & Deorum à suis honoribus cultus. Q. Curt. lib. 5. Sed quid erat, quod hoc honore Hamanam afficere Mardochaeus Judaeus noluerit? Et opinor quoniam Iudaeis non licebat perlegem patriam hominem adorare. Deus. Observat. l. 12. c. 1 • . and reprove them. Have no fellowship with the unfruitfull workes, &c.

After this you tell us of Mordecaie not honouring Haman. You are sore straitned when you bring this, to prove yours may despise Magistrates. Alas for you, that you are faine to take this for a cover. Doe not you know Haman was a Heathen, a profest enemy of God, and a contriver to destroy the Church of God? Ours are no Heathens, no open Hamans, and yours are few of them Mordecaies. Ours tell us, they professe Christ and the Gospell, and are set up to help the Church. Againe, doe not yon know the honour that was given to Persian Princes, was more then civill, as the Jews thought, a kinde of adoration, like to that they gave to God, and Mordecai was afraid to come neere to Idolatry? Their Princes tooke a kinde of Divine, and more then civill state on them, and zealous Jewes were afraid of the Lords jealousie, giving that to another was due to him.

You tell us Christ called Herod a Fox. Make our Magistrates appeare as open enemies to Christ as Herod was, and let us know you are as holy, as wise, as good as Christ, and then you may have some more liberty this way. Presently you present us with Paul calling Ananias a whited wall, for striking him contrary to Law. You minde not, that Paul corrects himselfe presently for
that, as a fault, and slip of his forward tongue, and confesses he spoke heedlesly that word,Act. 23.3, 4, 5. Hierome attributes it to Pauls infirmity, lib. 3. contra Pel. And Osiand. in loc. If Paul speaks Ironically, it warrants not you. For High Priests after Christ was ascended into the Holy of Holyes in Heaven, were but whited walls, there needed no Typicall High Priests, the true High Priest being come, and having offered his perfect sacrifice. Our Magistrates take upon them to be High priests. When they said to him, Revilest thou Gods High Priest? He said, I wist not, brethren, that he was the High Priest, for it is written, thou shalt not speak evill of the Ruler of the people. I am of their judgement that make these words of Pauls, I wist not to be thus much, I considered not, I heeded not, or I was overseene. I did it in haste. I am much more willing to take it so, then to make Paul speake Ironically, as if he said, I wist not, that I saw any thing of an High Priest, or lawfull carriage of a Magistrate according to Gods command, that I should acknowledge him so; however be it thus, Paul might speake further then every private person may: Neither are our Magistrates brought in by the Roman power, as Ananias, neither are these that revile them Pauls. You bring in afterwards of Magistrates called Beasts, Dan. 7. and you tell us of a Scarlet coloured Beast, Revel. 17. I wonder you have not a Scarlet coloured face to blush for making such grosse comparisons, twixt Heathen Tyrants, Antichrist, and our Christian Magistrates.

Your good woman at the Castle sent out a large paper, to make Judges, and Lawyers, and Ministers to be Beasts, and according to her name, she houts on them. Onely she tells the world that the Saints must now judge, for the Sonne of God is come to judgement already.

div.head: Antiquaer.
div.p: The last thing I shall deale in, in this Antiquaerie is, that you defend your peoples language of Thouing the Magistrates; for so did Paul use Thou to all Magistrates. Then you say we speak Thou to God, and why not to Men? And if it should not be used in English, as well as in other Languages, why did not the Translators of the Bible put in You instead of Thou?

div.head: Reply to Antiquaer.
div.p: For the language of Thouing Magistrates and others, there were not so much fault to be found with it, but for these two things.

First, that it seemes to be taken up by you in a way of contempt, and singularity of uncourteousnesse, and banishing of a lawfull urbanity and civill behaviour to be used to all men. For which you may I know, say you use it to all, and so it is done impartially.
Yet that may be made a colour to excuse your surly language to strangers, because you use it to familiars: as the covetous Churle excused his pinching dieting of his servants with an Egge at a meale, because he tooke but one himselfe, but that was to promote his niggardise the better.Mat. 5. I could tell you that the Scripture of despitefull speech and rash anger, Raca, and reproaching our brother, is by some Divines that may be your Tutors and mine, interpreted a scornfull and bitter Thouing, a man, when we would vilifie him all we can. And it is well known you tooke not up this language, till you tooke up this way of proud singularity, to depart from the manners of the common faith. I am in some d • sire to know, whether according as you pretend it a generall way of languaging it, you Thou your Fathers and Mothers or no? and if you doe, how they looke at these wanton chickins, that are so saucy with them?

Secondly, I must tell you, that it is the common courteous language of the Country to You one, and there being no sin,1 Pet. 3.8. Be Pitifull, be Courteous. no not in appearance in it, I know not why you should refuse it. If you say the Translators in the Bible and other Countries used Thou, I answer, the custome of our Countrey is to use You. With all which, you minde not other Countries and languages tempered their Thous with civility, Obvios quosque si non occurrit nomen Dominos salutamus. Seneca. John. 20.15: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
usurparunt Graeci in Salutationibus. Desider. Heraldus in Animadvers. ad Mart. that you might know it was not of contempt, every one they spoke to that was a stranger they called Sir, as Mary called a poore Gard • er, as she thought, Sir, though it was Christ, but she knew it not.

For the use of Thou to God in the Scriptures, and in our prayers, there is some reason, lest if we should use the plurall number, it might be suspected we dreamed of more Gods then one; and therefore it was needfull the singular number should be retained in our speaking to God, and of God. There is no necessity of speaking alike in all things to man, as we doe to God: because I say Thou to my Heavenly Father, it doth not follow that I must say Thou to my earthly Father also.

div.head: QƲAERIE XI.
div.p: Whether the Nation of England be not blind of both eyes, when they doe not see the designes of Satan by these, and such like instruments to tread under foot both Magistracy and Ministery?

div.head: Antiquaer.
div.p: If the Nation of England be blind of both eyes, then whether is it not high time to remove their teachers, who have got their moneyes all this while, and communicated no light to them, but left them blind?

div.head: Reply.
div.p: You would faine teach me the Art of Railing, I know no Calling you follow else, but I will not learne it. Yes, there are in England that see with both eyes your designes and delusions. If they did not, holy Ministers might be faultlesse, that have offered them boxes of Divine eye salve. The use of the meanes is by the Ministers application, the blessing is of Gods application. I thought you had known a Text sounding thus, I have planted, and Apollos watered, 1 Cor. 3.6. Prov. 20.12. but God gives the increase. Or this, the hearing eare and the seeing eye the Lord hath made even both of them, both Corporall and Spirituall senses: but you are wilfully blind in this. You tell us it may be they have got light some other way, to see the designe of God against corrupt Magistrates and blind guides. I wish they may see to purge the Land more, but your spectacles will give them a corrupt fight, for all Magistrates and Ministers must goe dwell in the Levell by your advise. I wish, that which you call light be not meere darknesse.

div.head: QƲAERIE XII.
div.p: Whether this be not the high-way highly to offend God, and grieve Gods Spirit, to say, that standing naked on the top of a Crosse in a Market-place, a mans lying naked, and a womans comming to lye with him, is commanded them by God, and by the Spirit of God, that so they should doe?

div.head: Antiquaer.
div.p: Whether Isaiahs being naked did grieve the spirit of God? Isa. 20. And if theirs be not of that nature, but their worke be made to burne, then they shall suffer the losse of that worke, 1 Cor. 3.15. But where hast thou any Scripture for crying out for punishment upon their bodies for being naked? And whereas thou speakest of a woman comming to lye with a naked man; whether wouldst thou not here insinuate a lye under ambiguity of words?

div.head: Reply to Antiquarie.
div.p:
Seekers are like Africa, though they be in Europe, they alwaies bring forth some Monsters. Here is a Monster of Ignorance and
Blasphemie. Of ignorance in alledging Isaiahs nakednesse to cover your Clients nakednesse. Of Blasphemy, in asking a foolish question, whether Isaiahs nakednesse grieved Gods Spirit, and thereupon giving us to take on trust a simple it may be, these naked Clients of yours had as good allowance from the Spirit of God. It is Blasphemy to say the Spirit of purity is the patron of uncleannesse: or, that they had as good warrant as Esay.

For Esayes nakednesse, since I know you travell not farre in Expositors, your owne Spirit commonly being your large notes on the Bible. I shall leade you no further then Junius and Tremel. who will tell you this nakednesse of Esayes was onely the putting off his Shoos, and his large upper garment, which was his Propheticall mantle, and then he was said to be naked, though he had an under and shorter garment, which shewed some nakednesse of Thighs and Leggs. When the Jews cast off any outward ornaments, they used to weare ordinarily, they are said to be naked. David, when he laid by his Royall upper Robe and danced before the Arke, Michal charges him with immodesty, for uncovering himselfe, and making himselfe too naked,2 Sam. 6.14. & 20. and yet it is well seene there, that he was not altogether uncovered, for he was girded with a Linnen Ephod. Exod. 32.25. The people in Exodus that contributed their golden earerings to the making of the golden Calfe, are said to be naked, for Aaron had made them naked to their shame. Now their nakednesse was this, first they were bereaved of their golden Ornaments. Secondly, by their golden Idolatry. A consequence of it was this, they were made naked and stript at present of Gods favour and pleasure, he finding them in Idolatry. As for your Blasphemous collation of Esayes being commanded by the Spirit, (and therefore his nakednesse was not likely to grieve the Spirit) with the nakednesse of yours, I pray you in time learne to keepe your heart from entertaining such thoughts as that all the extravagancies of yours come out with Heavens privilegio as well as the Prophets and beest Seers of God. I shall grant you these two things for yours, First, that they did not make themselves naked but by a Spirit. Secondly, That notwithstanding their nakednesse grieves the Spirit.

I believe the nakednesse we speak of in yours, was from a spirit, a spirit of delusion, Satan setting them on: a spirit of corruption, their owne darke and corrupt hearts prompting them to such immodesties; which light of nature would lend them a restraint for.

And secondly, judge you whether all uncleanenesse in the very appearance doth not grieve the spirit of God: You come afterwards with an [If] their nakednesse be not of that nature, their worke shall burne. Still Etanorthosis and secret confessions are in fashion with you. Were it not better for them to turne from such pranks, then to doe that which must burne afterwards, and they be ashamed of it? Besides, their works burning hereafter, neither you nor I can safely passe our words, that their hearts are freed from burning lust here in these acts of theirs.

1. For naked man and naked womans comming to him, you ask two things, whether there be any Scripture to punish their bodies for nakednesse? 2. Whether the Quaerer have not some ambiguous meaning and sense lie in it?

For punishment, the Quaerer mentions none, but asks if it be not the high way to offend Gods spirit; yet since your minde runs all on punishment, I pray whether doe not many Scriptures tell you of Gods prohibitions of lusts, and of mens lying with other mens wives, or with single women, to whom they are not marryed, with threatnings of wrath?
For a lie under ambiguity of words, you may frame in your thoughts what you please, your Adam and Eve without any ambiguity, did shew nakednesse and come one to another, and it is too well knowne.

div.head: QƲAERE XIII.
div.p: Whether did Paul or this people say right, when Paul said, The works of the flesh were Adulterie, Fornication, Uncleanenesse, Lasciviousnesse; and yet t • ey say, they are fruits of the spirit, and the power of God urges them to them?

div.head: The Antiquaerie.
div.p: Where, or when didst thou heare any of them say, that Adultery, Fornication, Ʋncleanenesse, &c. were the fruits of the spirit? or which of them have been urged to these things?

div.head: Reply to the Antiquaery.
div.p:
Some of them have beene heard to say so; your man in prison
that lay naked some dayes, and the naked woman came to him, answered publiquely at the Assizes, the power of God was upon him, he was commanded to doe it. O the patience of God! God is a righteous Judge, strong and patient, and God is provoked • verie day. The man they say, is since dead, and so no more of him; his Eve is alive yet. Aske no more lest your eares tingle to heare, and your eyes glow to read the story of Wighton, where two Goats of that herd met together, a man and woman, he having a wife elsewhere, yet she at night comes from another bed to his, being of her transing sect, and bids him open to her, for the Father had sent her. He did so, till the man his bedfellow rose, and the shamefull immodesty was discovered. This is no lie in ambiguity of words, but is to be called into qu • stion, as being falne under the Magistrates cognisance, a knowne thing. The Father sent her, so he did; the Father of uncleanenesse, and impurity. Bullinger Advers. Anabapt. l. 2. c. 2. & 3. This brings to my minde, that which holy Bullinger reports of one sort of Anabaptists, in their country, that were called Liberi, the free ones, they held (saith he) community of wives, as well as of goods; that women ought to be whores, and uncleane, and prostitute their chastity, for so they should become greater in the Kingdome of Heaven then honest and chaste matrons, because Christ hath said,I know one said to me, that if he saw a mo • e spiritual beauty in a woman then in his wife, shee was nothing to him in comparison of the other. His meaning made good that which is much talked on the formality of marriage when the fancy doth another. the Publicans and Harlots goe into the Kingdome of Heaven before Justiciaries, and other more honest persons. They held that being regenerate and re-baptized, they could not sinne, it was the flesh onely that sinned, and not they. And when they committed any lewdnesse or wickednesse, they used to say, this was the will of the Father. And they had an invention to call their lying with whom they would, Spirituall Marriages; a rare way to save women, to perswade them to be uncleane. I could shew you an agreement of our Quakers to those in divers of these things, and that they have beene heard to talke of being married in the Spirit to those that were not their Husbands or Wives. But this will be enough to meet with their Lawyer, and non-suit him for all his pleadings, when he sees an woefull agreement betwixt his and other blinded wretches of old, both in language and practises. What neede I tell you, that according to their judgement, all this nakednesse and lying together may be without lust? it was Adam and Eve in their innocency,
they were naked, and were not ashamed. These are perfect soules indeede, that can lay fire and gun-powder together to touch one another, and yet they shall not burne. Sure it may be the Devill is reviving the invention of Vastalla, a rich and noble widdow of old at Millaine in Italie, Cael. secund. Cur. in pasq. Ecstatico. who set up a sect of men and women that should imitate Adam and Eve in their purity. Among other practises of that sect this was one, their Adam, and Eve, their Man and Woman were to lie naked in bed together, and if all the night long they could be found to abide without thinking, saying, or doing any thing about tasting of the forbidden fruit, then they were judged to be innocent, and become Angels, and to live the life of God: and it was diligently to be sought into what they had done; but if it were found otherwise, that they had desired and tasted forbidden fruit, and that Eve became a mother after ten moneths, they were excommunicate and cast out of Vastalla's Paradise, and put away with shame from them, condemned to labour and travell in the world.

And if you cast off your wanton wagge and wench for their prankes at Wighton, and be ashamed of them, as well you may be ashamed of their principles also,But for shortnesse sake I could tell of more naked ones. which belong to and agree with the principles of the rest; for such principles will naturally beget more of these practises. If they lie together, they will prove the kinred of fornication and uncleanenesse; you need not much plead for this, since in your Replie to the 21. Quaere, wee have your confession, crying guilty for two, I say three, one naked on the Market Crosse at Kirbie-Moores side, and two others lying naked, of which one suffers imprisonment, as you acknowledge, for owning that action to be of God.
This obscaenity of Wighton indeed fell out since, so that you have two more.

div.head: QƲAERE XIV.
div.p: Whether this be not the ready path to Atheisme, to make nothing of the outward command of the Word, Magistrates, Ministers, but onely to hearken to what is within one, and if the Devill and Spirit of delusion be there, it must be counted the voice of God?

div.head: Antiquaerie.
div.p: Whether the Spirit that speakes in thee, be not a lying spirit, in seeking to make men believe they make nothing of the outward command of the Word, when as their lives and words come neerest to the outward Rule of any thou canst set before them? &c.

div.head: Reply.
div.p: For the Quaerers Lying Spirit, if yours be a true Spirit, he is in a good part acquitted, because you have confessed nakednesse discovered, and obscaenity, and that he judges, so I, is a making nothing of the outward command of the Word, which bids wee should abstaine from all appearance of evill, and provide things honest in the sight of all men—You come on fiercely, saying, their lives and words come nearest the outward Rule of any thou canst set before them. Now the Lord teach you to put a Corke in that mouth, that dare vent and poure out such stuffe: Are their lives nearest to the Rule of the word, who delight to raise tumults in the peaceable gathering together of Saints? Is this neer to the outward Rule, to discover nakednesse and obscaenity, which would make civill and quiet Gentiles blush? Remember what has beene said before, and will be proved, and then your lavish lips and pen will fully be reproved for fathering false and prophane things upon a Gospel-conversation.

div.head: Antiqu.

p.hi: Then like Alexander the Coppersmith, you give out false and copper language against the Preachers of the Gospel, saying, that they make preaching a trade to got mony by, make merchandize of the word, they are hirelings of men, rather then Ministers of Christ.

div.p: To this I shall answer you hereafter, when the spirit of rayling comes afresh upon you againe, and for present leave you among the hirelings of Satan, whom he hath hired to blaspheme the Gospel of Christ, and the minstery thereof.

div.head: Antiqu.

p.hi: As to Magistrates, wherein are they against the just commands of Magistrates?

div.p:
I will answer you: The Magistrates should be keepers of peace and order, your people will know none, but transgresse against the end of Magistracy, our living a quiet and peaceable life in all godlinesse and honesty. They are against the observing of the Lords day, and other extraordinary dayes of publique worship, as nothing appertaining to them, though the Magistrates office is to see them observed. And for their goodly reckoning of Magistrates, we have heard before of your calling them Beasts, that is, all such as are not for you. One of your Libertine crew travelling
last publique Fast in October, and his Beast he rid on being taken till he paid his Fine for breach of the Parliaments Ordinance, he answered he knew no Lawes, nor Rule upon earth, but the word of God, and God ruler of all. In this he knew not the word of God; which saith, Let every souls be subject, &c.
The plea and defence for Ministers shall be made afterwards at the 26. Quaere and Antiquaerie.

div.head: QƲAERE XV.
div.p: Whether those Magistrates be not most faithfull friends to their Country and office, that do most labour to restraine their riots and tumults, that we may lead a quiet life in all godlinesse and honesty?

div.head: Antiquaerie.
div.p: Whether are these people, who quietly passe to and fro, or an heady people gathered together to stone and beat them the Rioters? And whether is not he, who encourages that brutish behaviour amongst the people, worthy to be accounted the head of the Ryoters? &c.

div.head: Reply.
div.p: Concerning this peoples passing to and fro quietly, we have heard there is little to that purpose, and for others which you suppose ours gathering together to stone and beat them if any prove so unorderly; neither doth the Quaerer, nor this Replyer go about to justifie them. But the desire is, all may be done legally and orderly: your selfe know they have had the benefit of the Sessions, where there has beene colour or appearance of unlawfull setting upon them, though they first provoked them by undue actions. As Ryoting is punished in your people, so let ryotous usage be punished in ours: no sober Christian that I know will be an Advocate for any that proceed against yours without the bounds of Law and Gospel; the rest is a clawing of yours for innocent and harmlesse, and a railing on all others for riotous assaulters that will not walke as they do. That above will serve reason, nothing will stop railing.

div.head: QƲERE XVI.
div.p: Whether a quiet and honest Papist be not a Saint in comparison of these, though both of them be Idolaters, the one worshipping the fancy of Rome, the other the fancy of his Braine?

div.head: Reply.
div.p: Much do I wonder you make no Reply to this, but onely to the 17. Quaere, and this onely of all the rest is omitted. Certainely, for any thing I can see, there is a great deal of agreement betwixt these and Papists; Papists were not mentioned for any credit of their faith, but for quietnesse and orderlinesse in the point of their conversation, in which they are far more harmlesse then yours.
1. Is it omitted because you would have every one walke according to their owne light, whether it be a Roman candle, which is but a snuffe, or a Jerusalems light?
2. Or is it because yours and they goe the same way, and thinke to make your Christ, Justification, and Salvation out of your owne Regeneration, Mortification, denyall of the world, good works?

3. In all the writings I have seene, this of yours, many letters of theirs, there is scarce a word of salvation by Christ, his bloud, merits, sufferings, but all runs upon new-birth, selfe-deniall, light within one, Christ in a man, and Christ without apprehended by faith to be our sole righteousnesse, is not at all mentioned by any of yours. If this be not a kinde of Popery, a faire gate of Rome, I am deceived, and so are others too; and take heede some Roman spirits doe not lead on these poore soules, and deceive them; take heed there be not a Roman Foxe to lead and guide your Lambs.

div.head: QƲAERIE XVII.
div.p: Whether the toleration of these be not more intolerable then the walking about, and toleration of Bedlamers and frantick people, since these cannot perswade others to be mad; but by spirituall delusions the other draw our wives and children all over the land to spirituall madnesse?

div.head: Antiqu. Reply.
div.p: I love not to render railing for railing.

div.head: Reply to Antiqu.
div.p: Truly you do not here, but render railing being not railed on, and presently you set upon it, as if you had commenced M. of that black Art, and therefore I shall leave the rest, it being nothing but railing and reviling, and no way answering the Quaere it selfe.

div.head: QƲAERE XVIII.
div.p: Whether there be not a great deale of ignorance and blindenesse in the Nation, when the people that doe not act those things, doe yet speake well and favourably of the obscaenity, immodesty, disorders, irregularity of these wandring starres?

div.head: Antiquaerie.
div.p: What obscaenity, immodesty, &c. is that which thou clappest upon the necks of all this people? Is it that nakednesse thou spokest of before? If it be, what canst thou doe with it, but let it rest till the day of triall, which shall discover every mans worke of what sort it is?

div.head: Reply.
div.p: Well said, and like a Catholique moderatour, let it rest till the day of triall. Not so Sir, there is another saith otherwise, Reprove them sharply, Tit. 1. Ephes. 5. that they may be sound in the faith; have no fellowship with the unfruitfull workes of darkenesse, but reprove them rather. What a faire end you make of all? O that Absalom were a Magistrate, or Prince in Israel, he would doe all men right. If one came and complained to him, one hath drawne away my Wife, and she followes another: one hath seduced my onely Sonne or Daughter; one hath got my Sister with child, another hath pulled the Minister out of his Pulpit, and when he was preaching, called him hireling, wolfe, sorcerer, deceiver, false teacher, &c. another called all the Magistrates masters of bribes, &c. What shall be said of this? our compleat Justice here would set all right in a few words. Go home, let them alone, let every one follow the light that is within them, let all alone to the day of triall; here is Justice indeed. 'Tis pity you gave not the Parliament directions for the Copy of an Oath, to Justices of Peace: What a common wit you have to constitute a Common-wealth?

div.head: Antiquaerie.
div.p: Then you bring us in the harmelesse dealings of yours, meeting without disorder to speake to one another, and edifie one another in love, crying out against sinne in the open streets, going into Synagogues, and crying down Parish hirelings for deceivers and seducers.

div.head: Reply.
div.p: This is pretty orderly indeed, and you say, though we count it disorder, yet it was once order; for Paul used to reason in the Synagogues, Acts 17.2. Reasoning you say is not a set oration of one alone, but others to speake as well as he. It is said, Paul for three Sabbath daies reasoned with them out of the Scriptures, that is, for three Sabbath dayes he preached unto them Jesus Christ & he proved him to be the Christ by arguments and reasons drawne out of the Scriptures, which is the Scriptures of the Law and Prophets applyed to Christ. You have after in the third verse, that he was opening, and alledging, that Christ must needes have suffered and rise againe. This reasoning of his was preaching, for it was alledging Scriptures, and opening, that is, expounding the true meaning of them: we see afterwards there were lewd fellowes of the baser sort that railed against him in the City, and raised an uproare: we heare of none of their reasonings in the Synagogue, but of their rising and railing in the City. If any of yours be preachers, as Paul was, and will preach faithfully the word of God, you may reason and open the Scriptures: but if you condemne all teaching in any but yours, and true teaching of Jesus Christ, and have no orderly nor sober way of discoursing with teachers after their businesse, but both in and after men and women cry out deceivers, dogs, hirelings, and why suffer you them? here is neither rime nor reason, but plain Rabshakisme and open railing, as if they meant to act the parts of dogs and swine, tearing and rending.

For your wandring starres applyed to Ministers, rather than to yours, who have no certaine settled abiding place in earth where to lay their heads, whereas Ministers, you say, wander from truth of Scriptures, I leave you to reviling and wandering, and wandering and reviling. No, the fault of Ministers with you is, they will not wander up and downe, but desire to shine in their owne Orbes with the light of truth: yours you say have no setled habitation, therefore me thinkes this proves them wanderers; why have they not settled habitations? They had Callings, Wives, Husbands, Parents, Children, Masters, Servants, Friends, why wander they abroad, and runne from them, and from their good friend the truth?

1. Wandering Starres are false teachers, called by the Apostle Jude, that are like the Planets, which are carried with another motion then other starres; so are yours, they will not be guided by the orderly light of the truth, but their owne braines are their Scriptures.

2. Or Wandring Stars are those that seeme to strike and glide aside in the heavens, which we commonly call running or falling starres. These are not starres indeed, but a running hot inflamation in a dry aire: so these seeme to shine with a forme of light and holinesse; but alas, this makes them no starres, this is but an inflamation of deceived spirits; they are dark and want true light in them.

3. Or lastly, they are called Wandering Starres, because they deceive and lead into wanderings and errours, and if yours do not deceive, and are deceived, love to wander, and cause others to wander, let truth judge.

div.head: QƲAERIE XIX.
div.p: Whether this be not strange Divinity, or strong Vanity rather, that they may leave Callings, be obscaene, revile, be disobedient, care neither for Order, nor Office; yet they sinne not, but are perfect?

div.head: Antiquaery.
div.p: Why dost thou lye to say they leave their Callings? And if some of them be called from their outward callings, and be sent forth by the Lord to Minister the word unto others, is not this a cleaving to that Calling to which they are called?

div.head: Reply.
div.p:
Who calls men and women now to leave their outward Callings? what voyce of God called your men from the plough, your women from the Distaffe to Minister the word to others? A little calling will serve them to leave their Callings. Doe not you know the Spirit of God saith, let every man abide in that Calling, that is, that outward Calling of Master, Servant, &c. wherein the Lord hath set him? He is not to thinke that his spirituall Calling doth abolish and nullifie his civill Calling.1 Cor. 7. When Christ calls any by his grace to himselfe, he doth not call him from his office and condition of civill exercise wherein he was. But why trouble I my selfe about this, since the Apostle is so
plaine? Presently you rage, and your tongue is so hot, or your stomack that fills your pen, that you have need of a sober Julep to coole you, and bring you acquainted with Christian moderation. For then you poure it out, that Ministers are afraid of discovering their nakednesse, and therefore would have them locked up in callings, prisons, any where to be rid of them. When Ministers doe not according to the Gospell let them heare of it, but truly, soberly, with a spirit of Christian reproofe, to amend, not to enrage them.— You excuse them, they doe not revile, no more then Christ in calling Pharises, blinde guides, Hypocrites, painted Sepulchers. For obscaenity and such like, you never heard an immodest word come out of their mouthes. But you have heard of immodest actions, lying together as above, nakednesse, &c. and you were faine to be their botcher, to make up some poore covers for their nakednesse. For Lording it over their Consciences that you speake of, it needs not.Romans 14. If they would have their faith to themselves, none would trouble them, but when their fire goes out of their owne harth to the burning up of other houses, to seduce, beguile and the like, to restraine the publique spreading of poysonous infections, is no Lording it over the Conscience.

To that of being perfect and without sinne, you say this: I think they are neerer to that condition then thou art who revilest them. I thanke you Sir, in behalfe of the Quaeter, he expected no lesse, when he heard who was the Judge. You seeme to allow their bragging of perfection, and being without sin, what neede a man to goe to Heaven for perfection, since he may have it here at their sh • ps? So the Familists of old said, they were as perfect as Adam and Eve, and we may beleeve them, as perfect and without sinne, as Adam in the day of his fall, stript of the image of God, perfectly corrupt, and defiled in all powers both of soule and body.

div.head: QƲAERIE XX.
div.p: Whether this people have not light upon some better Scripture then Christ hath given us, which tells them, that perfect iniquity, is perfect sanctity?

div.head: Antiquaer.
div.p:
I wonder thou canst invent such a lye against thaem, wilt thou not cease to adde lye to lye? who ever heard such a Tenent come out of
