their mouths? or how can any such thing be gathered from their lives, when as they abhor the workes of darknesse more then any?

div.head: Reply.
div.p: They had need be excellent, for your Trumpet blowes loud, and proclaimes them with great pietie and praise. Some flowers of your Rhetorique we have all along, of the Quaerers lying and adding lie to lie, these make well to the filling up of your booke. To prove it a lie, you say, who ever heard such a Tenent come out of their mouthes? Are you Malchus? who cut off your eare? Though you have it not immediatly from their mouthes, yet you have heard what you know will be proved to be very true, that a woman lying with another womans husband said the Father had sent her. First now spell, and then put together, and it will come to as much as this, that perfect iniquity is perfect sanctity. For if these fleshly lusts be iniquity (as I thinke they are) and yet it is the doing of the will of the Father, it is perfect sanctity if it were so: Remember for the rest your Adam and Eve.

div.head: Antiqu.

p.hi: At length you blow your Trumpet till your cheekes swell againe, in behalfe of this people, for their praise. They abhorre workes of darknesse more then any; they are free of swearing, drunkennesse, revelling, banqueting, gluttony, sports, excesse, pride, covetousnesse, uncleanenesse, foolish talking, jesting, suits, strife, quarrelling, defraudings and over-reaching.

div.p: If a man should say to me, take this vessell, here is no rats-bane, spider, &c. and reckon up a great many poysonous things, it were no great commendation if there were other as poysonous things that are not mentioned at all, as toads, vipers, aspes, adders, henbane, &c. Thus here you tell us they are not entertainers of such and such vices, but they have as bad and worse: they follow not drunkennesse, but they are drunke with spirituall pride, to thinke themselves as high in prophesie and inspiration, as Moses, Esay, or Paul. I could give you a note of particulars, that they are evidently guilty of, and will be judged workes of darknesse and fruits of the flesh.
1. As evill speaking, they say the Devill is in every one that agrees not with them.
2. Clamours, and cryings out in quiet Assemblies, with all bitter revilings,
3. Busibodinesse in other mens matters, while all lies at sixe and sevens at home.
4. Defrauding of Creditours, by impoverishing themselves through wandering abroad.
5. Strife and quarrelings are ordinarie with them, if they see but the face of one is not theirs.
6. Blaspheming of the Ordinances of God, and all outward teachings.
7. 8. 9. Envy, heresie, conceit of perfection, and some other high things, which will fall as low as works of darknesse.
I may do you the kindnesse a little below to let you know a little more.

div.head: QƲAERE XXI.
div.p: Whether when they will be naked, deny meat for some dayes, and use some other strange pranks, they goe not both against light of nature and light of Scripture?

div.head: Antiquaerie.
div.p: Concerning nakednesse, why dost thou mention it, as if they were all accustomed to be so? when as thou canst produce but two persons, who were so acted, and one of them suffers imprisonment for owning that action to be of God: And how knowest thou but God may make them signes as he did Isaiah, to discover thine and others nakednesse? &c.

div.head: Reply.
div.p: Sir, If you please we will set these Coleworts by, because they have beene twice boyled and set on the table: besides we have your confession; yet if you hearken but to some poore ignorant, seduced ones in the Dales, there are many may be heard of that did run starke naked upon supposition and presumption of regained Paradisiacall purity.

After you argue à mirabili, wondering any will write of their abstaining from meat certaine dayes, when Scripture speakes so much of Saints fastings, Moses and Christ forty dayes a piece, Esther three dayes, Ninevites, David, Daniel, Ezra, Johns Disciples, Paul, our Saviours giving rules for fasting, Mat. 6.16.

Fault is not found for their fasting, but because it is meere fasting
without praying, preaching, meditating. Alas, the Devils fast alwayes, but they pray not; we heare of yours fasting, but nothing of their praying, or any devout humbling before the Lord, and confessing of sins. Fasting is a leane and poore thing, unlesse Prayer and Devotion fatten it.

The propounding of Moses and Christs 40. dayes fast, is idle, and to no purpose, since they were extraordinary and miraculous, altogether beyond Rule.Our Saviour gives no Rules for fasting without praying and other acts of Humble Devotion and seeking God, and therefore it must be done in secret, yours fast and doe it openly, and in imitation of Moses and Christ, thinking to be miraculously fed from Heaven, and so tempt God. Yea they preferre these outward acts of bodily exercise before faith in Jesus Christ.
As for other strange pranks, (you say) I know not what they are, and nothing being mentioned, I can say nothing of them.

You shall have something mentioned further, a man beyond Malton, If you would know more, and that true too; a woman at Cave boasting of turning water into wine, and casting out Devils, and that her Lord bad her; she affirming it done, others denying it done, she said her Lord had put a lie upon her, and she p • esently fell mad. he need not be named, caused his Oven to be heated and shut up with onely aire and heat in it, and perswaded his wife at the time of drawing, she should finde it full of meate. This is miraculous working, marvellous ignorance, and marvellous tempting of God; for he and she found nothing but their owne follies and empty conceits. This is both against light of Nature and Scripture, to looke for blessings to arise without meanes and helpes, and to thinke God shall attend to worke marvells at the desire of every fancifull heart.

div.head: QƲAERE XXII.
div.p: Whether it be a good thing to maintain without any limitation, or bounds, we have fought for our liberty, and we will have our liberty?

div.head: Antiquaerie.
div.p: How can they maintaine this without any bounds, when they cannot use the sword to procure it, being kept within the bounds of peace voluntarily? And is it unreasonable for them to desire as free borne Inhabitants of England, an harmelesse and innocent liberty, especially seeing some of them have fought for their liberty, as well as other men?

div.head: Reply.
div.p:
You shall not much be medled with here. The Quaere I suppose is propounded upon this ground, that some thinke they may take liberty, nay licence to doe any thing, because it has beene fought for; liberty, an holy, confined liberty has been fought for,
but no licentious liberty and boundlesse for any to do what they will. For voluntary abiding within bounds you say it, we see it not, but as we see the mastiffe in the chaine, biting, snarling, struggling to be out of it. The rest needs not any thing to be said to it, a liberty of free-borne English being granted to all, so that it be liberty that Law and Gospell, Reason and Christian Religion sets out.

div.head: QƲAERE XXIII.
div.p: Whether the Lord be more displeased, or the Devill more pleased with these practises and principles, vented, spread, increased?

div.head: Antiquaerie.
div.p: The Lord is in his servants, the Devill is in his servants, &c.

div.head: Reply.
div.p: The summe of your Antiquaerie is conjuring as well as you can to raise up the Devill to goe amongst all them, and abide with them, that will not abide on the Quakers side: and for yours, God is among them, they are harmless, innocent Lambes, Doves, little Ones, Babes in Christ. And yet for all this, these Babes, Doves, little Ones, Lambes, they cry and make a noise, their voice is heard in the streets and markets, and like the voice of Dragons, and roarings, and yellings, as if they were greater beasts. If they be Lambes, they are very unlike the Lambe of God.

div.head: QƲAERE XXIV.
div.p: Whether it concernes not the whole country, to move the Magistrates, or Parliament, or both; timely to provide some remedy, left the whole country be swallowed up by Divine permission in tumults, madnesse, disorders, and Anarchicall licentiousnesse?

div.head: Antiquaer.
div.p: Whether the whole Country, or onely the Priests, are in danger to be swallowed up by these people? If it be done by Divine permission, how canst thou, or any else, set themselves against it without danger?

div.head: Reply.
div.p: Sure the Country is in danger, when the pit of errours opens the mouth so wide to be swallowed up. As for these you call Priests, the Lord, whose Embassadours they are, being faithfull will protect them.

You come with this onset, If it be by Divine permission,
how canst thou, or any body else, set themselves against it without danger?

Yes, there is no danger to set our selves by holy and commanded wayes and meanes against those, which may afterwards appeare to be Divine permission.Acts 4.28. The Jewes, and Pilat, and the rest, did that in crucifying of Christ, which the hand of the councell of God determined before to be done, and yet they were sinfull and cruell in it; for the councels and permissions of God put no force upon the wills of men,Ad peccandum non adjuvamur à Deo, sed quod à Deo nos avertimus, nostrum est, & haec est voluntas mala. Aug. de peccat. merit. l. 2. c. 5. but they may freely act, and set themselves to act other wayes. The permission of God is not to be understood as the permissions of Tyrants, whose wills help and approve the wickednesse of men. God permits many things which he will punish, we are to looke at his preception and command, that is to rule us, and we are to bend that way, what ever his permissions be. The decrees and permissions of God do not take away but preserve the liberty and order of nature, and the free manner of actings instituted by God in the second causes,
Divine permission doth not lessen the guilt of our sinfull Commissions.
Though the offence must come, yet woe be to him by w • om the offence commeth. imposing no necessity and force upon them. By your kinde of arguing Judas, Pilate, Scribes did well in crucifying Christ, for they did as they were acted by Divine permission. I doubt all the wretched practises of yours, though crooked, are fathered upon the streight decrees, councells, and permissions of God, and so their sinnes shall be excused, and his councell accused. By this I see you have very little Divinity: Gods permissions are secret, his commands are open; I am to doe and forbeare to doe according to his commands, let his permissions secret be what they will. Secret things belong to the Lord, but revealed things to us and our children. If I act according to Gods open word and commands, it matters not what his permissions be; I shall be accepted, because I looke at the knowne will of God: Judas had done better, though it was Gods permission to resist thoughts and purposes of betraying his Lord. What followes is of your crying out of peoples furiousnesse, in beating with clubs and cudgels, stoning, casting dirt, ducking into water such as move not an hand against them, nor seeke revenge upon her for such cruelties, though by Law they might, for which there is answer ready. I never knew any of these things done in a small measure, but yours sought the full extremity of law, though yours gave the first onsets
and provocations: when law is used against them, they crie out on it; when they would make use of it, they applie themselves earnestly to it. If you say ours are faultie in doing any thing unjustly and tumultously, so grant I, and they that do it, let them suffer for it.

div.head: QƲAERE XXV.
div.p: Whether the men of Malton that burnt their goods, because they might bee abased by pride; had not better councell, even from Iudas, to sell them and give the price to the poore, whereas the fire devoured their goods and charity?

div.head: Antiquaer.
div.p: Whether thou and Judas be not both of one Counsell, in advising to sell their pretious things for the use of the poore? And whether is counsell of Judas and thine better to be followed in this case, then the practise of Moses, who burned the golden calfe in the fire. Exod. 32.20. and the practise of Hezekiah, who did the like with the brasen serpent: and of them in the Acts,Acts 19.19. who burned their books amounting to 50000. pieces of silver?

div.head: Reply.
div.p:
Sir, you had need to use your memorie sometimes, for it proves a false Register ever and anon. Judas and the Quaerer, you say, advise to sell their pretious things for the poore, and yet in the next lines you compare these precious things to the golden Calfe, brasen Serpent, and conjuring books; you count these no pretious things. Verily I thinke with the Quaeter they had done more good, if Judas had beene of their Councell,Erronious spirits of old were complained on, as De arena resticulas nectentes. Irenae. advers. Valen. lib. 2. c. 20. though I take him to have beene no good Lawyer, nor Gospeller; and so have given either the things, or value to the poore. What Devotion, what Charity was there to feede the fire with them? It had been more pretious Devotion, to have devoted these pretious things for good to some: I have oft heard of a rope of sand, at length you make one, and compare these fellowes burning of their ribbonds and silke, I know not whether lace too; with Moses burning the molten Calfe, Hezekiah breaking the brasen Serpent, and the burning of the Ephesian conjuring Books in the Acts. I hope you are awake, but you talke as in a dreame. Compare you ribbands to the molten Calfe, Serpent, conjuring Books, that were directly used for Idolatrie, and Demonolatrie? O all you Mercers
and of the like Trades, here is one will complaine of you all to the Parliament, for selling molten Calves and conjuring Books. No marvell if they burnt them that were such dangerous things. I see Scriptures are ordinarily prest souldiers to fight for your fancies. I know not what to say to this ignorance and folly, 'tis best to leave you in your pleasant humour, that have found Scriptures to burne fine commodities under the notion of conjuring Bookes. Meat, Drinke, Cloathes, Horses, Dogs, Riches, all may be abused by pride and wantonnesse; and therefore all must be burned, (Coveteousnesse and Idolatry;) the Advocate pleades it, they are conjuring Bookes.

But Good Sir, why doe your Clients recant and sell of these kinde of goods againe? I beseech you send them word to quit themselves quite of these molten Calves, and brasen Serpents, or else you will plead no more for them.

div.head: QƲAERIE XXVI.
div.p: Whether any sober and pious soules, well grounded in, and cleaving to the word, can easily fall into these braine calentures, and dotages? And whether it be a thing fained and put upon them, or that the Judges and Assizes can witnesse it?

div.head: Antiquaerie.
div.p: I may let the former part of the Quaere stand good against thy owne selfe without altering one word.

div.head: Reply.
div.p: If you let the former part stand, it will not stand long, but it will fall towards your Clients.
For the last part, you say, what is it the Judges and Country can witnesse against them? any thing but what they openly confesse and stand for, even unto suffering.

It is not enough to suffer, but we must looke to the cause of our sufferings: The Apostle bids, let none of you suffer as an evill doer, 1 Pet. 4.15. or as a busie bodie in other mens matters. A man may boldly make confession of that which may be his confusion.

Ministery of England is much beholding to you, for in the end you say, your peoples fault is this, they ascribe Honour to God onely, and not to Men: they affirmed all the Priests of England, who preach for hire, are Theeves and Robbers.

Here I have writ as you did, Theeves and Robbers, with a great
Thiefe and a great Robber, because I know you take them to be great Theeves and great Robbers. For ought that I can see, they cannot rob you of much Divinity, Religion, or Charity: you are a Seeker, and they may goe seeke for it, and finde little in you. One would verily thinke, you are some Renegade Minister, have left your way, and therefore persecutes with your tongue all of that way. I have often heard it said, pardon a little Latin, Apostata est persecutor sui ordinis: If the Doctrine be good, the Application may lodge with the Advocate. But Good friend, why Thieves and Robbers are they? just as Physitians are, Theeves and Robbers that rob us of our diseases; so the Ministers are sent by God to rob the world of their ignorance, darknesse, errour, unbeliefe, the diseases of mens soules. By this it should appeare they are good Theeves, as the repenting Thiefe on the Crosse was called a good Thiefe: O but they preach for hire, they are hirelings. You have told us this oft enough, I could speake much for the Ministery, and I tell you truly, I doe verily thinke the Devill uses abundance of men and women now as his bellowes, to blow with his owne breath; you speake in this the very language of Hell: • f the Divell were on earth audibly and visibly to plead, he would plead as you doe against Gospel, and Ministers. All the world troubles him not so much as the faithfull Preachers of the Gospel: you tell of Hirelings, take heede you be not one of his Balaams, whom he hath hired to curse and revile Israles Ministerie: Have you no better names for them? Are they not the Embassadours of Christ, under-stewards in his House to give his family th • ir portion in due season? The Holy spirit, and Holy writings would have taught you to give them more honour. Now there is nothing comes from you but, Out upon them Hirelings: yet your people in their letters have given them company, for they write that the Judges, Lawyers, Magistrates, doe all for hire and bribes also. You would have Ministers (you said before) to be content with Christs allowance: Friend I tell you, Christs allowance is hire and maintenance, though you take it to be an odious word. Did not our Saviour bid his Disciples take reliefe where they came, with this reason, For the labourer is worthy of his hire? What will you make them? If they were Soldiers,Luke 10.7. you would allow them pay, Who goeth a warfare any time at his owne charges? 1 Cor. 9.
They are the good Soldiers of Jesus Christ, they are in his spirituall warfare. If they were Shepherds, they would be allowed for keeping the flock of perishing sheep; Who feedeth a flock, and eateth not of the milke of the flock? Mens souls are the Lords sheep, and these watch for their soules, Hebrews 13. Immortall sheepe, immortall soules: none grutches, rightly minded, assesments for Soldiers pay, none for Shepherds wages; onely Ministers must be termed Hirelings, because mens soules are counted base: yet againe I ask you, will not you use them as well as Soldiers, as well as Shepherds? How would you have them used? As beasts?1 Cor. 9.9, 10. I know you would, for you called them dogs and wolves. Well, let them be used like beasts then, and they must have maintenance; for it is written in the Law of Moses, Thou shalt not muzzle the mouth of the Oxe that treadeth out the Corne: Doth God take care for Oxen? Or saith he it altogether, saith Paul, for our sakes: for our sakes no doubt is it written, That he that plongheth should plough in hope, and he that thresheth in hope, should be partaker of his hope. Surely Satan muzzles both the Reason and Religion of such as you, that you cannot speake sense, but barke and bluster with railings and revilings, when you speake of the Minsters of the Gospel: you doe not onely judge them, but you make your selves a Judge of the Law. Verily the Lord will looke upon his faithfull Ministers,2 Sam. 16.12. and he will requite good for your cursing this day, as David said of the foreman of your Tribe, cursing Shimei.

div.head: QƲAERE XXVII.
div.p: Whether they say true, when they say they are the prophet Isaiah, Ieremiah, Ezekiel, &c. and therefore they may goe naked, and doe what they will? Or doe they not maintaine some transmigration of soules of others long since upon earth into their bodies? And if they have Isaiahs soule, what becomes of their owne soule?

div.head: Antiquaerie.
div.p: It is a tedious worke for me to answer to all frivolous Quaeries; neverthelesse lest thou shouldst be wise in thy own conceit, tell mee, whether Johns comming in the spirit and power of Elias, held forth a transmigration of soules? And if it did, what became of Johns soul? Cleare but this, and thou maist easily answer thy selfe.

div.head: Reply.
div.p:
Me thinkes it should be no tedious work to you to answer the Quaeres, for you do it as easily and idlely as may be. But O the great Knot that calls for a great wedge to rend it: John came in the spirit of Elias, in the spirit of his zeale, not with the same spirit and soule, therefore there is not to be any thoughts of any transmigrations. Sir, I have your meaning,Audax & impudens res est anima quae inani acre callescit. Irenae. Advers. Valentin. Haeres. l. 1. c. 9. yours in their bold actions come in the spirit of Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, &c. as John did in the spirit of Elias: we believe the last, because Christ told us so, but who are you that tels us covertly the first, that yours come in the spirit of the Prophets? we see nothing of spirit or practice to yours that is like to Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, &c. but as an Artichoke is like an Oyster, well worth midsummer conceits: the man conceited he was sent as Isaiah, and therefore hee puts off his cloathes and stands on top of the market Crosse. If the Scripture had told us halfe so much of yours as it hath told us of John and Elias, we might have given you some hearing; you know for the one we have Divine writings, for yours, comming in the spirits of the Prophets, we have vaine janglings; yet that which I told you of transmigrations, is a patch of these times of errours, or else the resurrection of the prophets. The Adorers of John Robins, (and you with yours are very fit to be such) tell us they meet with the Apostles and Prophets upon the earth every day; and I suppose your Transers heads are full of Jolly Robins too, for they would make us believe they are Prophets, and more then Prophets too: So they are, for they are false Prophets, and if they be any thing else in their unwarranted actions, they are the false Apes of the true Prophets. Nor neede you thinke it strange I speake of transmigrations, Pseudo-Christus Will. Frankland and Mary Gadbury the Lambs wife of late in Hamshire. for these monstrous last times have brought us out all kinde of prodigious follies. Have we not them that have affirmed themselves to be Christ among us? And of late yeeres doting has beene so in fashion, that divers vanities and blasphemies have come to view. I'le give you a touch of some, Bale out of Leland. Godwin in Bishops Liv. in Steph. Langton of Canterbury. and the Lord knowes there are many in the nature of these every day rising, and likely to rise more through the liberty of prophesying. In a Synod at Oxford there was once presented to the Bishop of Canterburie, Stephen Langton, a young man, that said he was Christ, and shewed the wounds, markes in his hands,
feet, side. He brought two women with him, whereof one took upon her to be the Virgin Mary, the other Mary Magdelen; but this false Christ was truly crucified and put to death for his blasphemy.

Guy de Bres. Mr. Baily.A woman at Apezel in Switzerland, did teach, and would needs perswade a number of Anabaptists, that She was Christ the Messias of the women, and she chose to her selfe twelve Apostles too.

John Becold of Leiden (all know) gave he was appointed by God to be King over the Saints,Lambertus. Hortensius. and to rule by Revelations of the spirit; the Prophets they had confirmed it, and said, O behold, the Father gives thee the sword, and calls thee to be King to reigne in Sion.

John 21.22Upon a willing mistake of these words, If I will that he tarry till I come; one would needes affirme John was not to die, but to live upon earth till Christ come againe,Beza in Annotat. Major. in Ioan. Evan. and he avowed himselfe to be that John, the beloved Disciple of Christ; but this false John was truly burnt at Tholous. For transmigrations, Loriottus a professor of Law at Leipsick, B • em. in Exer. Theol. affirmed, that his soule heretofore dwelt in an Ape, and that after his death it would goe into a Cock.

These are the fruits of Catabaptisme, Weigelianisme, Familisme, Seeking, Transing, alwayes passing into some strange dotages: Let but this people be attended and observed a while, and if you doe not heare of transmigrations, or worse, and higher blasphemies and apish follies, let me be censured by this geart Antiquaering Cato who I believe dare not promise, that these shall none of them run into such wild fancies, they having done pretily already in that kinde. Tell us not your men must act Esay and Jeremie and the like, unlesse you can prove transmigration, or give us Scripture for it,

div.head: QƲERE XXVIII.
div.p: Whether when about Malton there are towards two or three hundred neglecting their callings, meeting together, old and young, to compare notes of entransed madnesse, it concernes not a Church, nay a Common-wealth, if it were no more then Pagan, to looke to it, to prevent the growth of further mischiefe?

div.head: Antiqu.
div.p: Whether it be the spirit of Christ or Antichrist his enemy, that repines and rages to heare of the encrease of the number of such Disciples, as deny themselves of Honours, Pleasures, Riches, to follow Christ, &c.

div.head: Reply.
div.p: Would to God they followed Christ rightly. None ever despised the preaching of Gospell, and Ordinances of Christ, and at the same time could be said to be followers of Christ.

The rest of your speech is Salt-peter and Gun-powder, all spittings of reviles, as if speaking of the evill of these mens way were high persecution and Dragonisme, powring out a stoud to drowne the goodly man-child of their rare Religion.

Amongst these, another flower of your modest oratory falls into your discourse, but as a part of your seeking Antiquaerie. Whether is not this (say you) another lie added to the former, to say that there are about Malton, two or three hundred that neglect their callings?

In this no lie appeares, for in Malton there are many, and at Malton in the day of their Quaking Rendevousings and meetings, there were met together hundreds, sometimes it being a running fancy, and they meeting from divers parts there in a confluence, the East running to North and West, and sometimes they of the West running to the East. Lest this seeme strange to truth, you may be told that about Wakefield, Stanley, Holbeck, Rodwell, Kendall, they do divers times come from severall parts to make up great numbers, and I believe their callings lye in a transe, whilest they run far from home to follow these quaking Communions.

div.head: QƲAERE XXIX.
div.p: Whether these evils at Land be not worse then the Dutch at Sea, which call on us all to call on God for reclaiming poore soules from madly running on in Satans drove, and to preserve us, ours and the Country from being left to our lusts, lies and unevangelicall liberties.

div.head: Antiqu.
div.p: Whether Scotch, or Dutch, Papists, or any publique enemy that would over run the Land (if they would but let the Papists keepe their Hive) be not wished by thee, rather then a swordlesse weaponless people, who are against that hire, discovering the deceit of it by Scripture?

div.head: Reply.
div.p: I might well question whether you can write any thing without Worm-wood-water be in your Inke? or whether your book would have made one good sheete, but that railing against Ministers came in every leafe abundantly?

For Ministers hire you have beene answered before, and so has your Brother Rabshakeh, Tom Collier, b ene answered by others. You adde, if the Priests be able to defend themselves by Scripture against a people that use only the weapon of the Scripture, why do they cry out for help to the Magistrate? Ministers are able to defend themselves and the truth, and yet the Magistrate may be called upon to hinder tumults, pulling out of the Pulpit, interruptions of them in the Pulpit, seducing mens Wives to leave their Husbands, and the like, to the spreading of their poyson abroad.

div.head: QƲAERE XXX.
div.p: Whether this people, think there is any Christ, but Christ in them? And whether it be not a strange Christ that crosses his owne Gospell, Word, Practise, and Rule?

div.head: Antiqu.
div.p: Doe they not propound the example to thee, and the words to confound thy hire, if thou be a Priest, doe they not tell you that Christ calls such Theeves and Robbers, who come not in by the doore? and so forth.

div.head: Reply.
div.p: You have beene answered to the Priests hire, whether the Quaerer be one or no; for the rest that followes it is not answering, but bitter quarrelling; you say thy Christ that is in thee, and then by your old figure, thy Devill that is in thee (for you say you cannot call him Christ) rages against that which is an high lesson of selfe-deniall. Doe not over-heat your selfe with a scale fire of choller. You tell of persecuting, imprisoning, stocking of Christ in them. Is reviling of Magistrates and Ministers their Christ? Is other unorderly, immodest actions their Christ for which they are imprisoned? Would to God we could see more of Christ in them, and we should not complaine, or call for restraint: you have great need to repent of that word [greatly,] Thy Christ that is in thee railes against such meetings as the true Christ was conversant among. Os durum! What a bold heart is here, that writes with so bold a pen? Did ever any but this man say that the true Christ was conversant among such as these, and in such meetings? For by your words you would give to understand, Christs followers whilest he was on earth were all of these Perfectioners, and yet Quakers, which are very unsuitable, perfection and quaking. Which of the Disciples were in transes, and spoke idlely when they came out? Which of them in their meetings cryed out of Magistrates, and Preachers, and the true Christ among them liked it?

Now for a conclusion to your Antiquaeries, that all may know who read this, what kinde of rare Enthusiasts yours are: I shall set downe some of their opinions and tenents, which shall all be avouched from their writings by letters, and open speeches heard by many.

1. They doe hold themselves to be come into a state of perfection, when they are regenerate into their transing way,
Catharists. Familists. Donatists. Perfectus nemo est qui non magna mendacia apud ipsos producit.
Irenae. contra Valentin. l. 1. c. 15. you shall have for this, these words exactly according to one of their Letters. You make the people believe Christ hath but taken away part, and not all, (that is of sinne) where he speakes of perfection in part, he speakes of the growing from faith to faith, but where he speakes of the New Man, he speakes of the whole Man, redeemed wholly from the vaine conversation of the world, the Old Man being crucified and dead, and cast out, and
the New Man being raised, and reigning and ruling with power: then the acting of sinne is taken away, as well as the guilt and punishment. Here is a Perfectionist indeed, from whom the Acting of sinne is quite taken away.

Menandrians. Familists. Libertines.Theirs letters tell us, that the Resurrection is past already. Paul called this, in Hymeneus and Phïletus, prophane and vaine babling, and that which tends to overthrow the Faith. It is a mad conceit of the Familists, when a man is converted and renewed, the Resurrection is past, the great Trumpet is already blowne.

Familists.It followes upon this, that the Resurrection being past, the day of Judgement may be in this life too. So in their letter to the Judges they write, that now is the Sonne come to Judgement, and the Saints shall Judge the world. The Minister at Malton was opposed by one of them after Sermon before the Congregation, and accused of false Doctrine. Being asked how the charge arose, It was answered, he had taken away the Saints prerogative, and given it to God. For the Saints are to judge the world, and your Minister tells you, that God will judge the world. This is Familisme, making Christ nothing without the Saints, and no Christ but in them.
They commend a community of goods, and practise a living upon one another too much,Catabaptists. Familists. and too palpably, and urge it too far.

They make nothing of outward teaching of the word, Bread and Wine they call a Carnall Ordinance,Weigelianisme. Familisme. Zuenfieldianisme. Enthusiasts. Baptisme and Matrimonies they call Formalities, and tell of all these spiritually, onely to be looked after, and all inwardly onely to be taught, disgracing the word as a meere letter, and bidding hearken to that which is in them, though the light that is in them may be darknesse.

They Father all their bold and lewd speakings and doings upon the Spirit.Libertines. One of them having a letter railed against a Minister and his preaching grievously, with very lewd tearmes, he writ in the bottome, from the Spirit of God in such a man. He might better have said, from the Spirit of Blasphemy and bitternesse, then have fathered revilings and clamors upon Gods spirit, whose wisdome and carriage is gentle, pure and peaceable, James 3.

They looke for extraordinary raptures, inspirations, miracles, brag of miraculous healings,Montanists. and promise the casting of Devills out of men and women, making all to have the Devill in them that are not their way.
They wait for new things every day, and seeke for strange things as ever were among Prophets or Apostles.Seekers.

Applauded is by them the liberty of Prophesying, and what comes into their heads is all Spirit and Prophecy. Men, women, Iude's filthy dreamers, Socinians. boyes and girles, may all turne into Prophets and Preachers by Quaking, and all other Preachers and Ministers are but deluders and without calling.

Too much are they addicted to conversing with women, and setting on them, to seduce them and teach them all pranks,Carpocratians. Valentinians. Iren. l. 1. cap. 24. as being fittest to draw on others, after the manner of them in Apostles times, leading Captives silly women, and after the manner of Valentinians drawing women from their husbands, having some kinde of philtra & charitesia, to that purpose, inticings to love and follow them.

Imaginations have they of great liberty and freedome, Monasterian Anabaptists. Liberi, the free Anabaptists. that none should say or doe any thing by way of Rule or Command. Hence are cryed down Magistrates & Ministers as unlawfull callings, that they may onely Magistrate it, and Minister all things themselves.
Ministers to have no maintenance,Anabaptists in Common. Antiscripturists. not to preach upon Texts, though Scriptures tell us of both.

If their supposed spirit stir them up to it, nakednesse and other obscenities may be used, and all good,Tending to Adamites, Libertines, Enthusiasts. by the will of the Father, and command of G • d upon them.
A leaving all and running about to preach and cry out in Streets, Markets, House tops, every one that will, imagining he is called to it.
Thoughts that they onely are the people of God,Apostolick Anabaptists. and his Israel; and all others like Canaanites must be destroyed and rooted out by them.Huttite Anabaptists.

Regeneration and new birth is their Christ, justification, sanctification, perfection, all. All is confounded with and in this, Christ without them is little minded,Papists, Familists, Libertines this is that which states
them in innocency in a sort, and being regenerate and denying themselves, they may doe any thing, for it is Christ in them, which is a kind of Popery to be justified by grace in us. If they sinne, it is not they but the fl • sh, or as the Libertines said, it was their Asse that did it,Calvin. contra Libertin. c. 18. their outward man.

These all, and many more then these may be drawne from their letters written, their speeches, and principles, without straining of consequences. More might be mentioned, but their owne writings and doings will in a short time more lay them open.
FOr the Antiquerers answering of Scripture, he first gives answer to this Scripture, 1 Cor. 6.5.
His answer is plaine scolding with and reviling the Ministery.

The Reply I make is this. The Lord either teach him patience or rebuke him, for setting himselfe against Ordinances of God: For Ministers maintenance is Gods Ordinance. The Lord hath ordained that they which preach the Gospell,1 Cor. 9.14. should live of the Gospell.

div.head: The next Scripture he answers is this, 1 Cor. 14.33.
div.p: There he tells us their peoples speaking in the Assembly is not Confusion but Order, by that Scripture, 1 Cor. 14.30, 31. If any thing be revealed to another that sitteth by, let the first hold his peace. For ye may all prophesie one by one, that all may learne and all may be comforted. To this Scripture he brings, I bring this a true and full answer.

The Chu • ch of the Corinthians had such rare gifts of prophesie, miracles, tongues, that many besides him that first began to teach had the Spirit in an excellent manner inspiring them, that they were inabled to prophesie also. Let these tell and shew us for a truth, that their men and women that stand up and speak in the Assembly have the Spirit of God extraordinarily inspiring them, with rare gifts furnishing them, and then they may have
leave to speake in order. But now they let us see no extraordinary gifts but extraordinary boldnesse, they speake no Prophesies, but revilings and cursed language against Prophets and Preachers, and so this Scripture leaves them naked and will not cloth or cover them.

For these to stand up one, two or three together, absurdly to vent their owne vanities, without either inspiration or order, is meere confusion, and to say they speake by the spirit, thus speaking is blasphemy.

div.head: Another Scripture is, 1 Cor. 14.34, 35. About womens silence in the Churches.
div.p: Our great Antiquerer answers it quickly, that women are not excluded from speaking at all meetings, because of that Scripture, 1 Cor. 11.5. Every woman that prayeth or prophesieth with her head uncovered, dishonoureth her head. And then he addes that of Joel, the promise of the spirit to Daughters as well as Sonnes.

To this that he objects, of a woman praying or Prophesying with her head uncovered, is answered satisfactorily to as learned as the Antiquerer, that the womans Prophesying is the joyning in heart and minde to follow and attend him that Prophesies, but not openly to Prophesie as one performing an office in the Church, because even very women that had not the gift of Prophesie, were not to speake publickely in the Church, by that plaine prohibition of the Apostle, 1 Cor. 14.34, 35. 1 Tim. 2.12.
Or Secondly, which some rather cleave to, the womans Prophesying in the Church, is the joyning with the Congregation in praising God by Psalmes and Hymnes.

Scripture thus calls the praising of God by Musick and Psalms Prophesying. Three times is Musicall singing called Prophesying, 1 Chron. 25.1, 2, 3. And when Saul was chosen to be King,1 Chron. 25.1, 2, 3. 1 Sam. 10.5. & 10. we finde he meets with Prophets with Psaltery, Tabret, Pipe, Harpe, and he Prophesied with them, that is, he sang with them.

For Daughters Prophesying as well as Sonnes, unlesse you can apply it better then Peter, Acts 2: it was fulfilled presently after
Christs Ascension into Heaven, when all the multitude of beleevers spoke with divers tongues. Whereas he writes, if they Prophesie, shall they speake to the walls or to people about them? I answer, first let us be sure that they Prophesie, and then we shall tell you where they may speake, or the Apostle will tell you, though they Prophesie, yet they are to be silent in the Church. 1 Cor. 14. withall, I could tell you that the knowledge of beleevers in the New Testament, as handmaids, and Servants, Sons and Daughter, is called by the highest name of knowledge in the Old Testament, Visions, Dreames, Prophesies, to shew that the knowledge of God shall very much abound in last times, and yet not constitute them publique Prophets, and put them in office.

div.head: Last Scripture is, 2 Thes. 3.6. & 11, 12. Against disorderlinesse.
div.p: To this the Antiquaerer answers, with disorder and railing, and he is there left to his owne humour. You excuse the Transers, and retort and returne busie medlings upon the Ministers, whom you are pleased to name Hirelings, and you are their paymaster, though you be not called upon to it, for such as you have, you give them, even bitter words, and the birth of malicious lips and heart. You close up all with 8. Queries, returned to the first Quaerer.

div.head: QUAERE I.
div.p: Your first Quaere is. Whether the Quaerer be not acted by a carnall spirit contrary to Pauls, who saith, the weapons of our warfare are not carnall? but the Quaerer cries aloud for the carnall weapons of the magistrate to subdue a peaceable, harmlesse people.

div.head: Answer.
div.p: To this you have had answer before, Magistrates are called upon to suppresse and restraine their riots,In the Apostles time there were no Christian Magistrates to call upon. disorders, Sabbath-breakings, pullings out of Pulpit, drawing mens wives and children from them, and you shall finde Paul appealing to the Magistrates often, in the Acts of the Apostles in case of defence, and saving him from conspiracies, unjust and violent tumults. He sends to the chiefe Captaine, Acts 23.17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23. withall he appeals to Caesar.
There are two other Quaeries I shall answer to, and we will put up the rest in the Advocates black boxe of slanders and bitter revilings.

div.head: QUAERE II.
div.p: Your second Quaere is, If this people were Tares ready to choake the wheat, yet whether doth not his counsell contradict the counsell of Christ, Math. 13.29, 30. where he saith, let both grow together untill the harvest, lest you pluck up the wheat with them?

div.head: Answer.
div.p: I knew whither you would run in the end to the Parable of Tares, which is the Sanctuary of Sectaries: But Sir,Asylam Sectarum parabola Zizaniorum. I must pluck you from the hornes of this Altar. This is the great Text for L • berty, as is conceived by Libertines, Nebuchadnezzars great Tree in the dreame,Dan. 4.12. (and these dreame on it too) the leaves whereof are faire, and the fruit much, the Beasts of the field shadow under it.
I shall manifest the weaknesse of this, to prove the Toleration of all intolerable Heresies.

1. It is a parable, and so the scope of it is to be taken, and every part of it is not to be made an argument. Now the scope of it is this, not to bridle Magistrates, but to moderate and order the forward zeale of Christs Disciples, and all holy ones to the end of the world; not to be too hasty, nor murmuring and repining at Divine Providence, because the wicked and unholy grow up and flourish in the earth with the godly, and because they are not all presently destroyed, remembring this, though men cannot do it in this day, yet there shall be a perfect riddance of them at the last day. They may doe their endeavour, and quietly leave the rest to God.

2. This is not spoken onely of Hereticks and false teachers, but all the children of the wicked one are Tares, in any kind of continued in ungodlinesse. All things that offend, and them that doe equity, are the Tares gathered for the everlasting fire.Mat. 13.38.41. Now Drunkards, Murderers, Adulterers, &c. are Tares, and that offend as well as Hereticks and false Doctors. And if Let them alone be given as a command to Magistrates and all men till the last day, by this our great Bible Scholiast, then marke what savourie
doctrine he gives Magistrates, they must let Traitors, Theeves, Murderers, all ungodly persons alone till the day of judgement, for they are Tares, children of the wicked one, offend▪ and doe iniquity.

3. This let them alone is not simply and absolutely to let them alone, but onely respectively to danger arising to the good in the too much punishing the evill. When there may be hurt to the wheat by plucking up the Tares, then it were better to let them alone, when the godly may be in danger to perish with the wicked.

4. It is not meant of Church and Doctrines that are false onely, but our Saviour expounds the field to be the world, and not the Church, and so all ungodlinesse in the world is to be let alone till the day of Judgement, if this be a command.

5. But let them alone is no command, but an inhibition of our Saviours of too much fiercenesse of spirit, or preposterous zeale, discontented that all is not pure and holy. For all this, Magistrates may punish, Ministers may rebuke, there may be excommunication, and Ecclesiasticall plucking up, and casting out of Tares before the last day, and this forbids it not. It is well observed by the learned Camero, that the Anabaptists, that the most fly to this Text, to clip the wings of Magistrates, which is not the scope of Christ, they themselves cast by this Text in their practice,Camero in Myrothec. Evangel. and are very earnest pluckers up of those they count Tares, and have the most direfull excommunications to cast out of their Church of any other.

6. Lastly, Christ expounds not these words, let them grow till the Harvest, telling us his meaning is, we should tolerate all sins and sinners till the last day, for then I conceive he should contradict himselfe, and be of another minde in heaven then he was in upon earth. For from heaven he hath declared himselfe to be against the toleration and letting alone of such as vent doctrines erroneous, contrary to the Gospell. To the Angell of the Church of Ephesus Christ bids write, I know thy works, and thy labour, Revel. 2.2. and thy patience, and how thou canst not beare them which are evill, and thou hast tryed them, which say
they are Apostles and are not, and hast found them lyars. Againe, this thou hast, Revel. 2.20. that thou hatest the deeds of the Nicolaitans which I also hate. To the Church of Th • atira, I have a few things against thee, because thou sufferest that woman Jezebell, which calleth her sel • e a Prophetesse, to teach and to seduce my Servants, to commit Fornication, and to eate things sacrificed to Idolls.— He doth not say, I am against thee, because thou wilt not let these false teachers, false men Prophets, false women Prophetesses, goe and Transe, seduce, deceive soules, which thou should suffer in this world, and let the day of judgement try them. No, he saith, I have a few things against thee, because thou dost suffer them. Either you in alledging the parable of Tares, contradict the sense and meaning of Christ there: or else you make Christ to contradict himselfe here, choose whether you will, you abuse Jesus Christ. The Lord give you a better seeing eye, and a more understanding heart.

div.head: QUAERE III.
div.p: The third Quaerie of our Antiquaerers is this, Whether Gamaliel or this man gave better Counsell, Act. 5.34, 35, 36, 38, 39. Where Gamaliel said, let them alone, if it be not of God, it will come to nought, but this man saith, move the Magistrate to subdue them?

div.head: Answer.
div.p: Gamaliel was a Doctor of the Law, but he pleads very poorely here, as the Antiquering advocate doth. Since you wait for an answer to your Q • aere, hold you, there it is. The Quaerer gave better counsell, more wisely: Gamaliel spoke unsoundly and sillily. I see one weake Advocate admires another, I wish better pleaders for me, then either of these two Doctors, when I have a cause in hand.

1. For your satisfaction further, lo, you shall see pure Gamalielisme, that is, poore Logick, and poorer Law. I grant you that God did good by this speech of his, the Lord making use of it as a moderare speech with some cold water in it, to mitigate the flame and rage of the Councell, and High Priest, that they fell not upon sentencing the Apostles to death, by their Law against false Prophets and seducers, as they were forward
enough, but that this man of gravity cryed to them, Walke soberlie, be not too hasty, take heede what you doe.

2. Yet I must tell you againe, his moderation is urged with very weake Arguments. If this Counsell or worke be of men, it will come to nought: if it be of God, ye cannot overthrow it. Alas he was ignorant, and spake doubtfully, with an If it be of God, of the Gospell of Jesus Christ, he spoke like an unbeleever. If it be of men, what need he say so, when he had heard of such a Birth, such a Life, such Miracles, such Holinesse, such a Death, such a Resurrection, Ascension of Christ, such holy lives, such rare teaching, great miracles and gifts of the Apostles, as might put him beyond Ifs and Hypotheticalls too, It is not of Men, this is above Man, it is all Divine.

3. With this reasoning, you and Gamaliel may say, let Traitors, let Witches, let Adulterers, let all abominable wicked practises alone, let Magistrates meddle with none of them, and salve all with a We shall see in the end whether they be of God or no. In the meane time it seemes Magistrates and Ministers must doe nothing in their office towards reproving, restraining of Heresie, or open wickednesse, but all must turne Seekers and Waiters, and by the event they waite to see, they must judge by perishing or prospering, whether the thing be of God or no. I thought by the word of God we might judge of things whether they be of God or no, better then by events.

4. Gamaliel and you, that seeme to have beene brought up at his feet, would have the Counsell, and so you would have all Christian Magistrates and Ministers to turne Neuters to the Gospell, that is, Seekers: Neither make nor meddle with it, nor trouble our selves with what is against it, neither prove and try any things that are against the Gospell, nor reprove them, but wait for God, and commit all without meanes and mediate redresses, to immediate providence.—No Sir, we are at a point with you, we know there is but one Gospell. With that knowledge of Jesus Christ we have in the Scriptures, we can tread over a thousand of your Ifs, and turne your If backward, and say, Fy upon all lying vanities, I hate vaine inventions, but thy Law
doe I love. We know in whom we have beleeeved, that without if or and, the preaching of the Gospell, and embracing of it is the counsell of Jesus Christ, and must stand to the end of the world. Yea without if or and, against old or young Gamaliels, Scepticks or Seekers, we are sure that the way of your common Enthusiasmes, unordinancing of Soules, leaving of Callings, railing of the Gospell Magistracy, Gospell Ministery is of man, and will in the end come to naught. Yet is it the duty of the people of God to pray against it, act against it, in restraining, reproving and spreading of these Cankers and deadly evills.
The rest of your Queries you may put among slanders and evill speeches.

div.head: A POST-SCRIPT IN Behalfe of the QUERER.
div.p: THe Antiquaerer findes fault in his Postscript, his Booke was not printed by him that printed the Quaeries, which is nothing to the Quaerer, but should be borne with by you, for why may not the Printer use the just Liberty of Conscience in this, to choose to print Truth, and refuse to print Errors? So far as I can finde the Quaerer hindred him not. Whereas you boast, the Quaerer set not his name, therefore doe not you: Truly to that I could well answer, it was a small thing, and he affected not to make himselfe knowne in this. Besides, it may be he would not take your word, that that people are of so harmlesse and innocent behaviour, but however as you have wisely concealed your name, and so let him if he will reason the case with you for his concealement. He intended no quarrell, but fair warning to take heed of Seducers. Sir, when you write, revile not, I have abstained from it all along, and have chose rather to be quick and pleasant with you, and shew you your weaknesse, rather then shew you my malice. If at any time you judge I have beene sharpe with a soft Scaberd, remember how you struck and laid about you with a naked sword. And so Philalethes bids farewell to Philodoxus.

div.head: Faults escaped, correct thus.
